revision.text:
{{Feminism sidebar |Variants (general)}}
'''Anti-abortion feminism''' or '''pro-life feminism''' is the opposition to [[abortion]] by some [[Feminism|feminists]] who believe that the principles which inform their support of women's rights also call them to support the [[right to life]] of [[Prenatal development|prenatal]] humans. Anti-abortion feminists believe abortion hurts women more than it benefits them.
The anti-abortion feminist movement began to take shape in the early to mid-1970s with the founding of [[Feminists for Life]] (FFL) in the United States and Women for Life in Great Britain amid legal changes in those nations which widely permitted abortion.<ref name="Oaks2000">{{cite journal |last1=Oaks |first1=Laury |last2= |first2= |year=2000 |title='Pro-Woman, Pro-Life'? The Emergence of Pro-Life Feminism in Irish Anti-Abortion Discourses and Practices |journal=Irish Journal of Feminist Studies |volume=4 |issue=1 |pages=73–90 |publisher= |doi= |url= |accessdate=}}</ref> FFL and the [[Susan B. Anthony List]] (SBA List) are the most prominent anti-abortion feminist organizations in the United States. Other feminist pro-life organizations include [[New Wave Feminists]] and Feminists for Nonviolent Choices.
== Views and goals ==
Anti-abortion feminists consider the legal option of abortion to "support anti-motherhood social attitudes and policies and limit respect for women's citizenship".<ref name=NWSA>{{Cite journal|last=Oaks |first=Laury |year=Spring 2009 |title=What Are Pro-Life Feminists Doing on Campus? |journal=[[NWSA Journal]] |volume= 21|issue= 1|pages=178–203 |url= http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/nwsa_journal/v021/21.1.oaks.pdf|doi=|pmid= |pmc= |issn=1040-0656}}</ref> Anti-abortion feminists believe that abortion is an action dictated by society and legal abortion "perpetuates an uncaring, male-dominated society."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Oaks|first=Laury|year=2009|title=What are Pro-Life Feminists doing on Campus?|url=http://muse.jhu.edu/article/263661|journal=NWSA|volume=21|pages=178–203|via=Gender Studies Database}}</ref> Laury Oaks, Associate Professor of Feminist Studies at the [[University of California, Santa Barbara]], writes that when abortion is legal, anti-abortion feminists believe, "women come to see pregnancy and parenting as obstacles to full participation in education and the workplace,"<ref name=NWSA/> and describes anti-abortion feminist activism in Ireland as more "pro-mother" than "pro-woman".<ref name="Oaks2000"/> Oaks has written that while Irish abortion opponents valorize child-bearing and are critical of the notion that women have "a right to an identity beyond motherhood", some, such as [[Breda O'Brien]], founder of Feminists for Life Ireland, also offer feminist-inspired arguments that women's contributions to society are not limited to such functions.<ref name="Oaks2000"/>
Anti-abortion feminist organizations generally do not distinguish between views on abortion as a legal issue, abortion as a moral issue, and abortion as a medical procedure.<ref name=NWSA/> Such distinctions are made by many women, for example, women who would not abort their own pregnancies but would prefer that abortion remain legal.<ref name=NWSA/>
Anti-abortion feminist organizations seek to personalize abortion by using women who "survived" abortions to attempt to convince others of their argument.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Between Jesus and the Market: The Emotions that Matter in Right-Wing America|last=Kintz|first=Linda|publisher=Duke University Press|year=1997|isbn=|location=Durham|pages=269|quote=|via=Gender Studies Database}}</ref>
Prominent American anti-abortion feminist organizations seek to end abortion in the U.S. The SBA List states this as their "ultimate goal",<ref name="SBA List Mission Statement">{{cite web|url=http://www.sba-list.org/about-sba-list/our-mission |title=SBA List Mission: Advancing, Mobilizing and Representing Pro-Life Women |year=2008 |publisher=Susan B. Anthony List |accessdate=October 18, 2010 |quote=To accomplish our ultimate goal of ending abortion in this country... |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141027042315/http://www.sba-list.org/about-sba-list/our-mission |archivedate=October 27, 2014 }}</ref> and FFL President Serrin Foster said that FFL "opposes abortion in all cases because violence is a violation of basic feminist principles".<ref name=NWSA/><ref>''The Nation''. August 11, 2005. Katha Pollitt. Reproductive Rights. [http://www.thenation.com/article/feminists-fetal-life ''Feminists for (Fetal) Life: subject to debate'']. Retrieved on May 11, 2009.</ref>
== Relationship to other movements ==
Anti-abortion feminists form a part of the [[anti-abortion movements|anti-abortion movement]] rather than the mainstream [[feminist movement]].<ref name=NWSA/> During the [[second wave feminism|second-wave era]] of the late 1960s and 1970s the tenets of the emerging group of anti-abortion feminists were rejected by mainstream feminists who held that for full participation in society, a woman's "moral and legal right to control her fertility" needed to be a fundamental principle.<ref name=NWSA/> From their minority position, anti-abortion feminists said that mainstream feminists did not speak for all women.<ref name=NWSA/>
Having failed to gain a respected position within mainstream feminism,<ref name=NWSA/> anti-abortion feminists aligned themselves with other anti-abortion and [[Right to life#Abortion debate framing|right to life]] groups. This placement, according to Oaks, has eroded a feminist sense of identity separate from other anti-abortion groups, despite pro-woman arguments that are distinct from the fetal rights arguments put forward by other anti-abortion advocates.<ref name=NWSA/>
== Arguments == The abortion debate has primarily been centered around the question of whether or not the fetus is a person.<ref>Markowitz, S. (1990). Abortion and Feminism. ''Social Theory and Practice,16''(1), 1-17. {{jstor|23557071}}</ref> Anti-abortion feminist organizations do distinguish themselves as "pro-woman" organizations as opposed to "fetal rights" organizations. This sets them apart from other anti-abortion groups.<ref name="NWSA" />
The "pro-woman" argument frames abortion as harmful to women. Anti-abortion feminists argue that women do not truly want to have abortions,<ref name="Alexa J. Trumpy 2014">Alexa J. Trumpy (2014) Woman vs. Fetus: Frame Transformation and Intramovement Dynamics in the Pro-Life Movement, Sociological Spectrum, 34:2, 163-184, {{doi|10.1080/02732173.2014.878624}}</ref> but rather are forced into abortions by third parties, partners or medical practitioners.<ref name="Alexa J. Trumpy 2014"/> These unwanted abortions, they say, cause physical and emotional damage to women.<ref>Melody Rose (2011) Pro-Life, Pro-Woman? Frame Extension in the American Antiabortion Movement, Journal of Women, Politics & Policy, 32:1, 1-27, {{doi|10.1080/1554477X.2011.537565}}</ref> By positing the existence of a "[[post-abortion syndrome]]" mental condition, which is not medically recognized, anti-abortion feminists reframe opposition to abortion in terms of protecting women's public health.<ref>Siegel, R. B. (2008). The right's reasons: constitutional conflict and the spread of woman-protective antiabortion argument. ''Duke Law Journal'', ''57''(6), 1641-1692.</ref> The "pro-woman" argument has been used to sway men and women against-abortion.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Righting Feminism|last=Schreiber|first=Ronnee|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2008|isbn=978-0-19-533181-3|location=New York|pages=99–101|quote=|via=}}</ref>
== 19th-century feminists == Feminist anti-abortion groups say they are continuing the tradition of 19th-century women's rights activists such as [[Elizabeth Cady Stanton]], [[Matilda Joslyn Gage]], [[Victoria Woodhull]], [[Elizabeth Blackwell]], and [[Alice Paul]] who considered abortion to be an evil forced upon women by men.<ref name="obeirne">[https://web.archive.org/web/20060203094203/http://www.nationalreview.com/kob/obeirne200601230842.asp Kate O'Beirne, excerpt from 'Women Who Make the World Worse: and How Their Radical Feminist Assault Is Ruining Our Schools, Families, Military, and Sports' National Review January 23, 2006]. Archived [http://www.nationalreview.com/kob/obeirne200601230842.asp from the original] on February 3, 2006. Retrieved on March 30, 2012</ref><ref name=EarlySuffragists>[http://www.sba-list.org/site/c.ddJBKJNsFqG/b.4137649/k.A53B/Early_Suffragists.htm SBA List – Early Suffragists] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100115020035/http://www.sba-list.org/site/c.ddJBKJNsFqG/b.4137649/k.A53B/Early_Suffragists.htm |date=2010-01-15 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/ethics/abortion/mother/early.shtml "Abortion and the early feminists"]. ''[[BBC]]''. Retrieved March 31, 2012.</ref> The newspaper, [[The Revolution (newspaper)|''The Revolution'']], published by [[Susan B. Anthony]] and Stanton, carried letters, essays and editorials debating many issues of the day, including articles decrying "child murder" and "infanticide."<ref name= "obeirne"/><ref name=McLaughlin2010>{{cite web |url=http://www.susanbanthonybirthplace.com/Media.html|title=Susan B. Anthony (Birthplace) House opens |last=McLaughlin |first=Peter |date=February 11, 2010 |work=The Eagle |publisher=Susan B. Anthony Birthplace Museum |accessdate=October 19, 2010}}</ref> According to historians A. Kennedy and K. D. Mary, Alice Paul felt that abortion was the "ultimate exploitation of women"<ref name=":1">Kennedy, A., & Mary, K. D. (1999). Feminism and abortion. ''History Today, 49''(8), 34-35. Retrieved from http://search.proquest.com/docview/202814071</ref> and worried about female babies being aborted.<ref name=":1"/> Kennedy and Mary also say that Elizabeth Blackwell, the first female doctor in the United States,<ref name=":1"/> became a doctor because of her passionate hatred for abortion.<ref name=":1"/> By way of criticism, however, sociologists Nicole Beisel and Tamara Kay have written that white [[White Anglo-Saxon Protestant|Anglo-Saxon Protestants]] (WASPs) in the US were worried that continued abortions by their kind would endanger their position at the top of society's hierarchy, especially fearing the influx of [[Irish Catholic|Irish Catholics]], but also concerned about African Americans, and describe Anthony and Stanton as part of this reactionary racial stance.<ref>Beisel, N., & Kay, T. (2004). [https://www.jstor.org/stable/3593062 "Abortion, Race, and Gender in Nineteenth-Century America."] ''American Sociological Review,'' ''69''(4), 498-518.</ref>
In arguing for "voluntary motherhood<ref name=":2" />" (abstinence until children are wanted), Stanton said that the problem of abortion demonstrates the victimization of women by men who pass laws without women's consent.<ref name=":2" /> Woodhull and [[Tennessee Celeste Claflin|her sister]] argued that abortion clinics would go out of business if voluntary motherhood was widely practiced.<ref name=":2">Gordon, L. (1973). Voluntary Motherhood; The Beginnings of Feminist Birth Control Ideas in the United States. ''Feminist Studies,'' ''1''(3/4), 5-22. {{jstor|1566477}}</ref>
A [[Susan B. Anthony abortion dispute|dispute about Anthony's abortion views]] arose in 1989: anti-abortion feminists in the U.S. began using Anthony's words and image to promote their anti-abortion cause. Scholars of 19th-century American feminism, as well as pro-choice activists, countered what they considered a co-opting of Anthony's legacy as America's most dedicated suffragist, saying that the anti-abortion activists are falsely attributing opinions to Anthony, and that it is misleading to apply 19th century arguments to the modern abortion debate.<ref name=Stevens2006>{{cite web|last=Stevens |first=Allison |title=Susan B. Anthony's Abortion Position Spurs Scuffle |publisher=[[Women's eNews]] |date=2006-10-06 |url=http://www.womensenews.org/story/abortion/061006/susan-b-anthonys-abortion-position-spurs-scuffle |accessdate=2009-11-21}}</ref>
== See also == * [[United States anti-abortion movement]] * [[Dorothy Day]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== Further reading == * ''The Cost of 'Choice': Women Evaluate the Impact of Abortion'' edited by [[Erika Bachiochi]] (2004, {{ISBN|1-59403-051-0}}) * ''Prolife Feminism Yesterday & Today.'' Second & greatly expanded edition. Edited by Derr, Naranjo-Huebl, & MacNair (2005, {{ISBN|1-4134-9576-1}}) * ''Prolife Feminism Yesterday & Today.'' edited by Derr, Naranjo-Huebl, and MacNair (1995, {{ISBN|0-945819-62-5}}) * ''Pro-Life Feminism: Different Voices'' edited by Gail Grenier-Sweet (1985, {{ISBN|0-919225-22-5}}) * ''Swimming Against the Tide: Feminist Dissent on the Issue of Abortion'' edited by Angela Kennedy (1997, {{ISBN|1-85182-267-4}})
== External links == *[http://www.fnsa.org Feminism & Nonviolence Studies Association]
{{Abortion}}

{{Infobox company | name = Boracay Water | logo =BoracayWater logo.png | logo_size =300px | caption = The brand logo of Boracay Island Water Company. | type = [[Private company|Private]] | foundation = [[Boracay]], [[Philippines]] | location = [[Boracay Island]], Balabag, [[Malay, Aklan|Malay]] [[Aklan]] , [[Philippines]] | key_people = Virgilio C. Rivera Jr., President & CEO (MWPV) | products = Water Delivery
[[sanitary sewer|Sewerage]] and [[Sanitation]] | homepage = | net_income = [[Philippine peso|PHP]]69.86 billion {{Down}}(2015) }} '''Boracay Island Water Company, Inc.''' (BIWC), branded as '''Boracay Water''', is the joint venture company of [[Manila Water|Manila Water Company]] through its subsidiary [[Manila Water|Manila Water Philippine Ventures]] (MWPV) and the [[Philippine Tourism Authority (Philippines)|Philippine Tourism Authority]] (now [[Tourism Infrastructure and Enterprise Zone Authority]]) that delivers potable water service, sewerage service, and eventually, drainage management under a 25-year Concession Agreement to cater the approximately 1,000,000 tourist and 30,000 local residents of [[Boracay|Boracay Island]], [[Malay, Aklan|Malay]], [[Aklan]], [[Philippines]]. Boracay Water was incorporated on December 7, 2009, and commenced its operations last January 1, 2010. It services the entire Island of Boracay governed by three [[barangay]]s namely Manoc-Manoc, Balabag, and Yapak, including the commercial districts popularly known as Stations 1, 2 and 3.{{cite web|title=Boracay Island Water Company|url=http://boracayisland.org/all-service-list/boracay-island-water-company/|website=Boracay Foundation Inc.|accessdate=9 July 2016|ref=BIWC}} Boracay Water was granted the exclusive right to operate, manage, and expand [[Water industry|water]] and used water facilities for a period of 25 years, renewable for another 25 years. The company was also granted the right to operate and maintain the existing [[Drainage|drainage system]] upon its completion. It assumed operations on January 1, 2010 and began rehabilitating the island’s water and used water infrastructure, to contribute to a sustainable environment and to the economic development of the island. It helps in keeping the island’s pristine beaches with the rehabilitation of the Balabag Sewage Treatment Plant, a facility that has consistently complied with the stringent pollution control parameters of the [[Department of Environment and Natural Resources (Philippines)|Department of Environment and Natural Resources]] (DENR) processing 6.5 million liters of used water per day. Used water service coverage is targeted to be raised by 75 percent by 2016.{{cite web|title=Manila Water Philippine Ventures {{pipe}} Boracay Island Water Company, Inc.|url=http://www.manilawater.com/Pages/Manila%20Water%20Philippine%20Ventures.aspx|website=Manila Water Company, Inc.|accessdate=9 July 2016|ref=biwc_mwc}} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Water companies of the Philippines]] [[Category:Companies established in 2009]]

revision.text:
[[File:Nursing area sign.png|thumb|[[International breastfeeding symbol|International breastfeeding sign]] to designate a private nursing area]] '''Breastfeeding in public''' is the practice of [[breastfeeding]] babies in a [[public place|public]] or semi-public place in open view of the [[general public]]. Social attitudes and legal protection of the practice varies widely. In many countries, both in the [[Global South]] and in a number of Western countries, breastfeeding in public is common and generally not regarded as an issue. In those countries, laws protect the nursing mother. In many parts of the world including Australia<ref>{{cite article|url=https://www.breastfeeding.asn.au/bf-info/breastfeeding-and-law/legalright|title=Breastfeeding in public - your legal rights|date=Aug 2016|access-date=12 Nov 2018|publisher=Australian Breastfeeding Association}}</ref>, some parts of the United States, and Europe, along with some countries in Asia, women have an express legal right to nurse in public and in the workplace. A few countries, such as Saudi Arabia, expressly forbid women to expose their breasts in public, even to breastfeed.
Even though the practice may be legal or socially accepted, some mothers may nevertheless be reluctant to expose a breast in public to breastfeed<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://internationalbreastfeedingjournal.com/content/3/1/11|doi=10.1186/1746-4358-3-11|title=Got milk? Not in public!|pmid=18680578|year=2008|last1=Wolf|first1=J.H.|volume=3|issue=1|page=11|pmc=2518137|journal=International breastfeeding journal|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080901211817/http://www.internationalbreastfeedingjournal.com/content/3/1/11|archivedate=2008-09-01|df=}}</ref><ref name=Vance_2005>{{cite journal | last = Vance | first = Melissa R. | title = Breastfeeding Legislation in the United States: A General Overview and Implications for Helping Mothers | journal = LEAVEN | volume = 41 | issue = 3 | pages = 51–54 | publisher = | date = June–July 2005 | url = http://www.llli.org/llleaderweb/LV/LVJunJul05p51.html | ref = harv | postscript = . | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070331220518/http://www.llli.org/llleaderweb/LV/LVJunJul05p51.html# | archivedate = 2007-03-31 | df = | access-date = 2008-12-30 }}</ref> due to actual or potential objections by other people, negative comments, or harassment.<ref name=Jordan_2002>{{cite book |editor-last=Jordan |editor-first=Tim |editor-last2=Pile |editor-first2=Steve |title=Social Change|page=233|publisher=Blackwell|year=2002|isbn=9780631233114}}</ref> It is estimated that around 63% of mothers across the world have publicly breast-fed.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Breast Feeding With Confidence|last = Cox|first = Sue|publisher = Meadowbrook Press|year = 2002|isbn = 0684040050|location = United States|pages = }}</ref> The media have reported a number of incidents in which workers or members of the public have objected to or forbidden women breastfeeding.<ref>{{cite web|title=Places Moms Have Been Shamed For Breastfeeding|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/09/18/dawn-holland-breastfeeding_n_1893681.html#slide=start|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=28 September 2015|date=September 18, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150929013228/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/09/18/dawn-holland-breastfeeding_n_1893681.html#slide=start|archivedate=29 September 2015|df=}}</ref> Some mothers avoid the negative attention and choose to move to another location. But some mothers have protested their treatment, and if the practice is permitted by law, have taken legal action or engaged in protests.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dawn Holland, Breastfeeding Mom, Asked To Nurse In Applebee's Bathroom|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/09/18/dawn-holland-breastfeeding_n_1893681.html|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=28 September 2015|date=September 18, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150929013228/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/09/18/dawn-holland-breastfeeding_n_1893681.html|archivedate=29 September 2015|df=}}</ref> Protests have included a public [[boycott]] of the offenders business, organizing a "nurse-in" or a breastfeeding [[flash mob]], in which groups of nursing mothers gather at the location where the complaint originated and nursed their babies at the same time. In response, some companies have apologised and agreed to train their employees.<ref name=legoland/>
{{TOC limit|2}}
== Attitudes by country and continent == {{anchor|Attitudes by country}}<!-- linked from [[Breastfeeding by country]] -->
=== Africa === [[File:Kabala_mother.jpg|thumb|A new mother in Kabala, [[Sierra Leone]] in West Africa nurses outdoors. ]]
In many areas of [[Africa]] breastfeeding in public is the norm. Babies are commonly carried on a mother's back in a length of cloth and merely moved to the front for feeding. The nursing mother may shield the view of the baby nursing, but generally no attempt is made to hide the baby and the mother's breast from view. When a baby is seen crying in public it is assumed that the woman with the infant is not the child's mother, since it is normally thought that she would feed the infant if she were the mother.<ref name="Breastfeeding in public">{{cite web | url=http://www.007b.com/public-breastfeeding-world.php | title=Breastfeeding in public around the world | publisher=007 Breasts | accessdate=15 October 2014 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141008045416/http://www.007b.com/public-breastfeeding-world.php | archivedate=8 October 2014 | df= }}</ref>
==== Morocco ==== Public breastfeeding is legal and widely accepted.<ref>{{cite book|title=Morocco: A Survival Guide to Customs and Etiquette|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZRyJAAAAQBAJ|first=Orin|last=Hargraves|publisher=Marshall Cavendish|year=2010|isbn=9789814435895|page=108|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180126185038/https://books.google.com/books?id=ZRyJAAAAQBAJ|archivedate=2018-01-26|df=}}</ref>
==== Sierra Leone ==== [[Sierra Leone]] has the highest infant mortality rate in the world. During a goodwill trip to the country, actress [[Salma Hayek]] breastfed on camera a hungry week-old infant whose mother could not produce milk.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/02/10/salma-hayek-breastfeeds-a_n_165676.html|title=Salma Hayek Breastfeeds African Baby (VIDEO)|publisher=Huffingtonpost.com|accessdate=May 10, 2009|first=Katherine|last=Thomson|date=February 10, 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090428160211/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/02/10/salma-hayek-breastfeeds-a_n_165676.html|archivedate=April 28, 2009|df=}}</ref> She said she did it to reduce the stigma associated with breastfeeding and to encourage infant nutrition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.babble.com/celebrity/public-breastfeeding-pictures-celeb-moms-photos/salma-hayek-3/ |title=Celebs Who Breastfeed in Public |accessdate=August 1, 2001 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130614085140/http://www.babble.com/celebrity/public-breastfeeding-pictures-celeb-moms-photos/salma-hayek-3/ |archivedate=June 14, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
=== Asia === [[File:Woman breast-feeding baby.jpg|thumb|200px|Indonesian woman breastfeeding in public.]] ==== China ==== Breastfeeding in public in China has traditionally been uncontroversial, and objection had been unheard of until 2010s. The recent few instances of objection are apparently an effect of magnification of the social media.
In Shanghai, breastfeeding in public is considered embarrassing by some, but it is also accepted by many. There have been calls for the establishment of babycare facilities in public places.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2007-01/27/content_794272.htm|title=Congress to consider privacy issue|work=chinadaily.com.cn|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090307105647/http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2007-01/27/content_794272.htm|archivedate=2009-03-07|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/opinion/2007-01/29/content_795228.htm|title=Breastfeeding in public|work=chinadaily.com.cn|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090620071708/http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/opinion/2007-01/29/content_795228.htm|archivedate=2009-06-20|df=}}</ref>
==== India ==== India has no legal statute dealing with breastfeeding. Prevalence and social acceptance vary from region to region.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} In rural India it is completely acceptable. Breastfeeding in public is not a norm in higher sections of society, but is quite common in the lower economic sections.
==== Malaysia ==== Discreet breastfeeding in public is accepted in Malaysia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.babycenter.com.my/baby/breastfeeding/tips-for-breastfeeding-inpublic/|title=BabyCenter mums’ tips for breastfeeding in public|location=Malaysia|work=BabyCenter|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120527144646/http://www.babycenter.com.my/baby/breastfeeding/tips-for-breastfeeding-inpublic/|archivedate=2012-05-27|df=}}</ref>
==== Nepal ==== Nepal has no laws about public breastfeeding. Public breastfeeding is common and widely accepted.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Breastfeeding in Public: A Global Review of Different Attitudes towards It|doi=10.15406/jpnc.2014.01.00040|last1=Komodiki|first1=E|last2=Kontogeorgou|first2=A|last3=Papastavrou|first3=M|last4=Volaki|first4=P|display-authors=etal|journal=Journal of Pediatrics and Neonatal Care|volume=1|issue=6|date=6 November 2014|issn=2373-4426}}</ref> It is not uncommon to see mothers breastfeeding their babies in public places such as buses, parks, restaurants, hospitals etc. in Nepal. In Nepalese society, breastfeeding a child is considered a must for the mothers. Mothers who do not or are unable to breastfeed their child are considered to be 'bokshi' - 'witch', and much social stigma is attached to it.
==== Philippines ==== In the Philippines, breastfeeding is protected by various laws, such as the ''Expanded Breastfeeding Promotion Act of 2009''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lawphil.net/statutes/repacts/ra2010/ra_10028_2010.html|title=R.A. No. 10028|work=lawphil.net|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305175720/http://lawphil.net/statutes/repacts/ra2010/ra_10028_2010.html|archivedate=2016-03-05|df=}}</ref> and the ''Milk Code of the Philippines'' (Executive Order 51).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lawphil.net/executive/execord/eo1986/eo_51_1986.html|title=E.O. No. 51|work=lawphil.net|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111028220002/http://www.lawphil.net/executive/execord/eo1986/eo_51_1986.html|archivedate=2011-10-28|df=}}</ref> Mothers are allowed to breastfeed in public. Employers are required to allow lactating employees breaks to breastfeed or express breastmilk. The law also states that the intervals should not be less than a total of forty (40) minutes for every eight (8) hour working period.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chroniclesofanursingmom.com/2013/03/more-on-legal-rights-of-breastfeeding.html|title=Chronicles of a Nursing Mom: More on the Legal Rights of Breastfeeding and Working Women|work=chroniclesofanursingmom.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402132748/http://www.chroniclesofanursingmom.com/2013/03/more-on-legal-rights-of-breastfeeding.html|archivedate=2015-04-02|df=}}</ref> Offices, public establishments such as malls and schools, and government institutions are required to establish lactation stations separate from the bathroom, where mothers can breastfeed their babies or express milk. The Milk Code prohibits the advertising of infant formula or bottle teats for infants under two years old.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcw.gov.ph/law/executive-order-no-51|title=Executive Order No. 51 - Philippine Commission on Women|author=|date=|work=pcw.gov.ph|accessdate=21 December 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161213114954/http://www.pcw.gov.ph/law/executive-order-no-51|archivedate=13 December 2016|df=}}</ref>
==== Saudi Arabia ==== Even though women can not show any part of their body in public, breastfeeding is an exception. It's common for women to breastfeed in malls and parks, and it is acceptable among the people in Saudi Arabia.<ref>{{cite book|last=Riordan|first=Jan|title=Breastfeeding and Human Lactation|pages=718–719|isbn=0-7637-4585-5|year=2005|chapter=The Cultural Context of Breastfeeding|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=-XhKfbW8ig8C&pg=PA718&dq=%22public+breastfeeding%22&lr=&ei=ciZfSfyiNoPAlQTF4tj7BQ#PPA715,M1|publisher=Jones and Bartlett|location=Sudbury, Mass.|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180126185038/https://books.google.com/books?id=-XhKfbW8ig8C&pg=PA718&dq=%22public+breastfeeding%22&lr=&ei=ciZfSfyiNoPAlQTF4tj7BQ#PPA715,M1|archivedate=2018-01-26|df=}}</ref>
==== Taiwan ==== Since November 2010 the ''Public Breastfeeding Act'' has safeguarded the right to breastfeed in public, while [[lactation room]]s are set up to deal with privacy and to provide access to hot water and power supplies, with fines against interfering with a mother's right to breastfeed.<ref>{{cite web | title=Public Breastfeeding Act | publisher=[[Ministry of Justice (Republic of China)]] | date=2010-11-24 | url=http://law.moj.gov.tw/Eng/LawClass/LawAll.aspx?PCode=L0070036 | accessdate=2011-08-26 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120710151515/http://law.moj.gov.tw/Eng/LawClass/LawAll.aspx?PCode=L0070036 | archivedate=2012-07-10 | df= }}</ref> After evicting a breastfeeding mother from the [[National Palace Museum]] on 18 July 2012 and enraging many Taiwanese website users,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://59.151.17.12/html/womenofchina/report/143187-1.htm |title=Taipei Museum Faces Investigation for Evicting Breastfeeding Mother |author=Liu Yunting |date=July 23, 2012 |work=Translated from Shenzhen Evening News |publisher=All-China Women's Federation |accessdate=August 14, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180126185038/http://59.151.17.12/html/womenofchina/report/143187-1.htm |archivedate=January 26, 2018 |df= }}</ref> the supposedly offending employee and her employer were both fined 6000 [[new Taiwan dollar]]s (about 200 [[United States dollar]]s), said the Department of Health, Taipei City Government ({{zh|[[:zh:臺北市政府衛生局|臺北市政府衛生局]]}}), but the Museum would appeal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theborneopost.com/2012/08/15/taiwan-museum-fined-for-stopping-breastfeeding-mum/ |title=Taiwan museum fined for stopping breastfeeding mum |author= |date=August 15, 2012 |work= |publisher=From AFP, posted at Borneo Post Online |accessdate=August 14, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305020534/http://www.theborneopost.com/2012/08/15/taiwan-museum-fined-for-stopping-breastfeeding-mum/ |archivedate=March 5, 2016 |df= }}</ref>
=== Europe === [[File:Lactancia bebe aire libre.jpg|thumb|Woman nursing her infant at pro-breastfeeding conference in Spain]] ==== France ==== Public breastfeeding is legal and widely accepted.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}}
==== Germany ==== While public breastfeeding is widely accepted, especially since the [[Movement of 1968]] when public "Nurse-Ins" ({{lang-de|Still-Inns}}) were common, there is no legislation that specifically addresses breastfeeding in public.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://eltern.t-online.de/stillen-in-der-oeffentlichkeit-normal-oder-obszoen-/id_20622508/index|title=Ist Stillen in der Öffentlichkeit obszön?|trans-title=Is Breastfeeding in Public Obscene?|website=T-Online|date=8 February 2013|language=de|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111010032553/http://eltern.t-online.de/stillen-in-der-oeffentlichkeit-normal-oder-obszoen-/id_20622508/index|archivedate=10 October 2011|df=}}</ref>
Paragraph 2 Article 6 of the [[German Basic Law|Basic Law for the Federal Republic of Germany]] provides that "the care and upbringing of children as the natural right of parents" while paragraph 4 "entitles every mother to the protection and care of the community".<ref>{{cite act|url=http://www.iuscomp.org/gla/statutes/GG.htm#6|title=[[Basic Law for the Federal Republic of Germany]] (Grundgesetz, GG)|article=6|date=23 May 1949|accessdate=31 August 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170323071619/http://www.iuscomp.org/gla/statutes/GG.htm#6|archivedate=23 March 2017|df=}}</ref>
==== Iceland ==== Public breastfeeding is widespread and uncontroversial.<ref>{{cite web|title=Taking care of children in Iceland|url=http://nordicmum.com/taking-care-of-children-in-iceland/|website=www.nordicmum.com|accessdate=20 November 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161010004640/http://nordicmum.com/taking-care-of-children-in-iceland/|archivedate=10 October 2016|df=}}</ref>
==== Italy ====
In Italy, public breastfeeding is legal and accepted by many. {{citation needed|date=April 2017}}
==== Netherlands ==== Public breastfeeding is common and widely socially accepted. There are no laws against public breastfeeding. Dutch law states that when an employee wishes to breastfeed her baby the employer is obligated to provide, for the first nine months after the birth, a suitable nursing room and allow for 25% of work time to be spent on feeding the baby or pumping while on pay. After the first nine months the employer is still required to assure conditions for breastfeeding are met (like timely breaks, nursing rooms, safe environment, etc.) but does not have to pay anymore for the time spent on breastfeeding or pumping.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.borstvoeding.com/borstbaan/wet.html|title=Borstvoeding.com: kenniscentrum voor borstvoeding - artikelen- Borst & Baan - Borst & Baan en de wet|work=borstvoeding.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130809055356/http://www.borstvoeding.com/borstbaan/wet.html|archivedate=2013-08-09|df=}}</ref>
==== Norway ==== Public breastfeeding is widespread and uncontroversial.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}}
==== Poland ==== Public breastfeeding is widespread and uncontroversial.{{citation needed|date=October 2018}}
==== Spain ==== Public breastfeeding is legal and widely accepted.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}
==== United Kingdom ==== Breastfeeding in public (restaurants, cafes, libraries etc.) is protected under the [[Sex Discrimination Act 1975]] under the provision of goods, facilities and services section. If the child is under six months old, the mother has additional protection under a 2008 amendment to the act which protects maternity rights. This is superseded by the [[Equality Act 2010]] which clarifies that a business must not discriminate against a woman who is breastfeeding a child of any age in a public place.<ref>[https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/85008/business-quickstart.pdf Equality Act 2010: What do I need to know?<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231001143/https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/85008/business-quickstart.pdf |date=2013-12-31 }}</ref><ref name=EqualityAct_2010>{{cite web | title=Equality Act 2010 | publisher=Office of Public Sector Information | date=2010-04-08 | url=http://www.statutelaw.gov.uk/content.aspx?activeTextDocId=3698792 | archive-url=https://archive.is/20121224171341/http://www.statutelaw.gov.uk/content.aspx?activeTextDocId=3698792 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2012-12-24 | accessdate=2010-08-27 }}</ref> Her companion(s) are also protected by this act.
A 2004 [[Department of Health (United Kingdom)|UK Department of Health]] survey found that 84% (about five out of six people) find breastfeeding in public acceptable if done discreetly; however, 67% (two out of three) of mothers were worried about general opinion being against public breastfeeding.<ref name="UK-DOH_2004">{{cite press release | title = Myths stop women giving babies the best start in life | publisher = UK Department of Health | date = 2004-05-10 | url = http://www.dh.gov.uk/PublicationsAndStatistics/PressReleases/PressReleasesNotices/fs/en?CONTENT_ID=4081944&chk=b8wDo%2B | accessdate = 2007-02-16 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20040519035042/http://www.dh.gov.uk/PublicationsAndStatistics/PressReleases/PressReleasesNotices/fs/en?CONTENT_ID=4081944&chk=b8wDo%2B | archivedate = 2004-05-19 | df = }} </ref> To combat these fears in [[Scotland]], the Scottish Parliament passed legislation safeguarding the freedom of women to breastfeed in public in 2005.<ref name=ScotlandBill_2005>{{cite web | title=Breastfeeding etc. (Scotland) Act 2005 | publisher=Queen's Printer for Scotland | date=2005-02-10 | url=http://www.opsi.gov.uk/legislation/scotland/acts2005/20050001.htm | accessdate=2007-01-24 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070504030837/http://www.opsi.gov.uk/legislation/scotland/acts2005/20050001.htm | archivedate=2007-05-04 | df= }}</ref> The legislation allows for fines of up to [[Pound sterling|£]]2500 for preventing breastfeeding of a child up to the age of two years in public places,<ref name=BBC_2004>{{cite news | title=MSPs approve breastfeeding move | date=2004-09-23 | publisher=BBC News | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/scotland/3682824.stm | accessdate=2007-01-24 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060613201452/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/scotland/3682824.stm | archivedate=2006-06-13 | df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scotland.gov.uk/Publications/2006/07/04152607/1|title=The Breastfeeding etc. (Scotland) Act 2005: Advice for Employers|work=scotland.gov.uk|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231001038/http://www.scotland.gov.uk/Publications/2006/07/04152607/1|archivedate=2013-12-31|df=}}</ref>
==== Vatican City ==== In 2014 during a ceremony commemorating the [[Baptism of Jesus]], [[Pope Francis]] voiced his support for mothers breastfeeding their children in public spaces, including churches. On 9 January 2017 he reiterated his support for public breastfeeding.<ref>{{citeweb|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/01/09/508927895/pope-francis-reiterates-support-for-public-breastfeeding|title=Pope Francis Reiterates Support For Public Breastfeeding|author=Rebecca Hersher|date=9 January 2017|work=[[National Public Radio]]|accessdate=9 January 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170109213105/http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/01/09/508927895/pope-francis-reiterates-support-for-public-breastfeeding|archivedate=9 January 2017|df=}}</ref><ref>{{citeweb|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2017/01/09/go-ahead-and-breastfeed-pope-francis-tells-mothers-in-sistine-chapel/|title=Go Ahead And Breastfeed Pope Francis Tells Mothers In Sistine Chapel|author=Samantha Schmidt|date=9 January 2017|work=''[[The Washington Post]]''|accessdate=9 January 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170109112307/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2017/01/09/go-ahead-and-breastfeed-pope-francis-tells-mothers-in-sistine-chapel/|archivedate=9 January 2017|df=}}</ref>
=== North America === [[File:El origen de la Nación.jpg|thumb|A woman breastfeeding in the [[State of Mexico]] Congress tribune.]] ==== Canada ==== In [[Canada]], [[Section Twenty-eight of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms|Section 28]] of the [[Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms]] gives [[sex equality|equal rights and freedoms to men and women]], without explicitly mentioning breastfeeding. INFACT Canada (Infant Feeding Action Coalition) is a national non-governmental organization that aims to protect infant and young child health as well as maternal well-being through the promotion and support of breastfeeding and optimal infant feeding practices.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sterken|first=Elisabeth|title=INFACT Canada|url=http://infactcanada.ca/|accessdate=12 March 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140104214335/http://infactcanada.ca/|archivedate=4 January 2014|df=}}</ref> It is an organization that provides support and education for Canadian mothers.
Outside of degrading or dehumanizing purposes, law regards the breasts of women as equal to the breasts of men in Canada. See [[Topfreedom in Canada]].{{citation needed|date=July 2015}}
A woman asked in 2009 at a shop by an employee to stop breastfeeding publicly, supported by a manager, later received an apology and acknowledgement of customers' right to breastfeed.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://vancouversun.com/health/Walmart+apologizes+asking+stop+breastfeeding/1804833/story.html |title = Walmart apologizes for asking B.C. mom to stop breastfeeding, Ann Hui, ''The Vancouver Sun'' 18 July 2009. |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120115155043/http://www.vancouversun.com/health/Walmart+apologizes+asking+stop+breastfeeding/1804833/story.html |archivedate = 15 January 2012 |df = }}</ref> A worker at the [[YMCA]] in St. John's told a breastfeeding mother to leave the premises. The mother was feeding her seven-month-old daughter in a private change room, which required a monthly fee. YMCA CEO Jason Brown later apologized, stating "This situation has caused us to reflect and review, and certainly we see no reason why there should be a restriction to women breastfeed their babies in the adult-only change room."<ref>{{cite news|title=YMCA changes breastfeeding policy following complaint|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/ymca-changes-breastfeeding-policy-following-complaint-1.2555012|accessdate=13 March 2014|newspaper=CBC News|date=Feb 28, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140319065535/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/ymca-changes-breastfeeding-policy-following-complaint-1.2555012|archivedate=19 March 2014|df=}}</ref>
===== Inuit People ===== [[Inuit]] children have the lowest breastfeeding rates amongst Canadian Aboriginal populations, far lower than the Canadian average. According to a 2006 statistics report, 24% of Inuit children have never been breastfed. There have been health promotion programs created in order to increase the knowledge of the benefits of breastfeeding amongst Inuit women.<ref>{{cite report|last1=Asuri|first1=Sirisha|first2=Anna Claire|last2=Ryan|first3=Laura|last3=Arbour|title=Early Inuit child health in Canada. Report 2, Breastfeeding among Inuit in Canada|url=https://www.itk.ca/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/2011-Report-Breastfeeding-among-Inuit-in-Canada.pdf|format=pdf|year=2011|publisher=Inuit Tapiriit Kanatami|location=Ottawa|pages=5–8|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171027182510/https://www.itk.ca/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/2011-Report-Breastfeeding-among-Inuit-in-Canada.pdf|archivedate=2017-10-27|df=}}</ref>
==== United States ==== [[File:1920_tent_colony_in_Forest_Park,_St._Louis,_sketched_by_Marguerite_Martyn.jpg|thumb|right|Woman in center is feeding her baby in a tent city erected in 1920 by the Red Cross in [[St. Louis, Missouri]], so city families could get away from the August heat. (Drawing by [[Marguerite Martyn]] of the ''St. Louis Post-Dispatch.'')]] A number of issues constrain mothers from breastfeeding in public in the United States. In 2011 the [[Surgeon General of the United States|US Surgeon General]] issued a plea to promote breastfeeding and stated in it: "Although focusing on the sexuality of female breasts is common on the mass media, visual images of breastfeeding are rare, and a mother may never have seen a woman breastfeeding".<ref>{{cite report|publisher=U.S. Department of Health and Human Services|year=2011|title=The Surgeon General's call to action to support breastfeeding|url=https://www.surgeongeneral.gov/library/calls/breastfeeding/calltoactiontosupportbreastfeeding.pdf|page=13}}</ref> Breastfeeding is not only a human right for the mother but also the child in need of being fed. The child's health and human right can only be obtained through breastfeeding the child.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ohchr.org/EN/NewsEvents/Pages/DisplayNews.aspx?NewsID=20904&LangID=E|title=OHCHR {{!}} Breastfeeding a matter of human rights, say UN experts, urging action on formula milk|website=www.ohchr.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-06}}</ref> Another issue, especially in extended breastfeeding, is that US medical providers are not well-trained in supporting breastfeeding mothers. In a survey of medical professionals published in 2012, including physicians, midwives, residents, and nursing students, only 57.8% felt that breastfeeding over 1 year of age was normal.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cockerham-Colas|first1=Lauren|last2=Geer|first2=Laura|first3=Benker|last3=Karen|first4=Joseph|last4=Michael A.|date=June 2012|title=Exploring and influencing the knowledge and attitudes of health professionals towards extended breastfeeding.|journal=Breastfeeding Medicine|volume=Volume 7|issue=Issue 3|pages=143–150|doi=10.1089/bfm.2011.0027}}</ref> The recommendations for breastfeeding are until at least one year, yet in 2016 the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) reported that only 51.8% of infants were breastfed at 6 months and 30.7% of infants were being breastfed at 1 year old.<ref>{{cite report|publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|date=August 2016|title=Breastfeeding report Card|url=https://www.cdc.gov/breastfeeding/pdf/2016breastfeedingreportcard.pdf|page=2}}</ref>
In a 2004 survey conducted by the [[American Dietetic Association]], 43% of the 3,719 respondents believed women ought to have the right to breast-feed in public.<ref name="auto">{{cite news|title=Eyeful of breast-feeding mom sparks outrage|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/14065706/ns/health-womens_health/t/eyeful-breast-feeding-mom-sparks-outrage/|accessdate=25 November 2011|date=2006-07-27|agency=Associated Press|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111216101356/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/14065706/ns/health-womens_health/t/eyeful-breast-feeding-mom-sparks-outrage/|archivedate=16 December 2011|df=}}</ref> In some public places and workplaces, rooms for mothers to nurse in private have been designated.
U.S. legislation governing breastfeeding varies from state to state and a limited federal law only applies to federal government premises. A [[United States House of Representatives]] appropriations bill (HR 2490) contained an amendment specifically permitting breastfeeding<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d106:HZ00295: |title=Breastfeeding Amendment |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504153044/http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d106:HZ00295:# |archivedate=2015-05-04 |df= |access-date=2008-12-30 }}</ref> was signed into law on September 29, 1999. It stipulated that no government funds may be used to enforce any prohibition on women breastfeeding their children in federal buildings or on federal property. Further, a federal law also enacted in 1999 specifically provides that "a woman may breastfeed her child at any location in a federal building or on federal property, if the woman and her child are otherwise authorized to be present at the location."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.glin.gov/download.action?fulltextId=170184&documentId=67358&glinID=67358|title=Treasury and General Government Appropriations Act, 2000|accessdate=13 July 2012}}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} section 647.</ref>
Section 4207 of the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]] amended the [[Fair Labor Standards Act]] and required employers to provide a reasonable break time for an employee to breastfeed her child if it is less than one year old.<ref name=ppaca>[http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getdoc.cgi?dbname=111_cong_bills&docid=f:h3590enr.txt.pdf Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706032624/http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getdoc.cgi?dbname=111_cong_bills&docid=f:h3590enr.txt.pdf |date=2011-07-06 }}. ''Government Printing Office''. Page 459.</ref> The employee must be allowed to breastfeed in a private place, other than a bathroom. The employer is not required to pay the employee during the break time.<ref name=ppaca/> Employers with fewer than 50 employees are not required to comply with the law if doing so would impose an undue hardship to the employer based on its size, finances, nature, or structure of its business.<ref>{{cite news |title=Breastfeeding rooms hidden in health care law |work=CNN |date=April 9, 2010 |first=Elizabeth |last=Landau |url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/HEALTH/04/09/breast.feeding.society/index.html?hpt=C2 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924150714/http://www.cnn.com/2010/HEALTH/04/09/breast.feeding.society/index.html?hpt=C2 |archivedate=September 24, 2015 |df= }}</ref>
A number of incidents of harassment of nursing mothers which gained media attention prompted a number of U.S. states to act. These incidents included viral videos of people harassing breastfeeding mothers in public, protests, and social media campaigns. A particular incident with a [[Target Corporation|Target]] employee harassing a breastfeeding mother helped to launch a new trend with corporations making breastfeeding accepted in their stores.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.bestforbabes.org/target-employees-bully-breastfeeding-mom-despite-corporate-policy/|title=Target Employees Bully Breastfeeding Mom Despite Corporate Policy - Best for Babes|date=2011-12-14|newspaper=Best for Babes|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-10|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161017104458/http://www.bestforbabes.org/target-employees-bully-breastfeeding-mom-despite-corporate-policy/|archivedate=2016-10-17|df=}}</ref>
As of July 2018, all 50 states, the District of Columbia, and the Virgin Islands have passed legislation that explicitly allows women to breastfeed in public.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://people.com/health/breastfeeding-public-legal-all-50-states/|title=Breastfeeding in Public Is FINALLY Legal in All 50 States|work=PEOPLE.com|access-date=2018-08-08|language=en}}</ref> Further, at least 29 states, the District of Columbia, and the Virgin Islands exempt them from prosecution for [[public indecency]] or [[indecent exposure]] for doing so.<ref name="state legislatures">{{cite web|title=Breastfeeding State Laws|url=http://www.ncsl.org/research/health/breastfeeding-state-laws.aspx|website=National Conference of State Legislatures|publisher=National Conference of State Legislatures|accessdate=3 December 2015|date=2 September 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151130120629/http://www.ncsl.org/research/health/breastfeeding-state-laws.aspx|archivedate=30 November 2015|df=}}</ref>
=== Oceania === ==== Australia ==== Section 7AA of the ''[[Sex Discrimination Act 1984]]'' specifically prohibits discrimination against a woman on account of her breastfeeding.<ref>''[[Sex Discrimination Act 1984]]'', [http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/cth/consol_act/sda1984209/s7aa.html s.7AA] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150322113138/http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/cth/consol_act/sda1984209/s7aa.html |date=2015-03-22 }}.</ref> The prohibition also applies to a public or semi-public place. State and Territory laws differ, but it is generally illegal to discriminate against women breastfeeding in a public place as a protected attribute in five jurisdictions and by proxy from other existing legislation in the other jurisdictions.<ref name="breastfeeding.asn.au">{{cite web|url=https://www.breastfeeding.asn.au/bf-info/breastfeeding-and-law/legalright|title=Breastfeeding in public - your legal rights|work=Australian Breastfeeding Association|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121101012310/https://www.breastfeeding.asn.au/bf-info/breastfeeding-and-law/legalright|archivedate=2012-11-01|df=}}</ref>
The [[Australian Breastfeeding Association]] was founded in [[Melbourne]], Victoria in 1964 as the Nursing Mothers' Association, and together with many health professionals, encourages and assists mothers to breastfeed their babies, if necessary also in a public place.<ref name="breastfeeding.asn.au"/>
In February 2003, [[Kirstie Marshall]], member of the [[Victorian Legislative Assembly]], was ejected from Parliament for breastfeeding her 11-day-old baby on the basis that the baby was "a stranger" not entitled to be in the Chamber. As a result, a special room was set up for use by nursing mothers.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} A 2007 House of Representatives Committee on Health and Ageing report into breastfeeding recommended that Parliament House seek formal accreditation from the Australian Breastfeeding Association as a breastfeeding-friendly workplace. In March 2008 the Presiding Officers agreed to the recommendation and work commenced to provide facilities to assist breastfeeding mothers at Parliament House. Two small rooms were made available, one on each side of Parliament House, for members of parliament and other building occupants to breastfeed or express milk. Certificates of accreditation were provided in a ceremony at the parliament on 17 October 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aph.gov.au/About_Parliament/Parliamentary_Departments/Parliamentary_Library/pubs/rp/rp0910/10rp09|title=Children in the parliamentary chambers|work=aph.gov.au|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117030049/http://www.aph.gov.au/About_Parliament/Parliamentary_Departments/Parliamentary_Library/pubs/rp/rp0910/10rp09|archivedate=2015-11-17|df=}}</ref>
==== New Zealand ==== Breastfeeding is encouraged and public breastfeeding is common. In fact, bottle feeding has been so widely discouraged that public ''bottle'' feeding may make a mother feel more uncomfortable than public breastfeeding. Many shopping centers provide "parent's rooms" where mothers may change and feed their infants in comfort.<ref name="Breastfeeding in public"/>
=== South America === In most areas of South America breastfeeding is the norm and public breastfeeding is common in buses, parks, malls, etc. It is less common to see public bottle feeding than breastfeeding. While women are seldom seen nursing in upscale restaurants or on the streets of large cities, nursing is encouraged and thought of as normal and a nursing mother's breasts are not viewed as sexual objects.<ref name="Breastfeeding in public"/>
== Recent controversies ==
=== Breastfeeding at work in Canada ===
Under the [[Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms]] women are protected against discrimination, but Canada was one of the only countries that did not have paid breastfeeding breaks. Although over 26% of mothers breastfeed, many of them are forced to stop due to work restrictions.<ref>{{cite news|last=Heymann|first=Jody|title=Breastfeeding breaks at work pay off; Canada is in the minority of countries that do not guarantee women paid breaks to feed infants at work,|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1439984164|accessdate=11 March 2014|newspaper=The Ottawa Citizen|date=7 Oct 2013}}</ref>
=== Public breastfeeding in the U.S. ===
There have been incidents of owners of premises, or people present, objecting to or forbidding breastfeeding. In some cases the mothers have left. In other cases, where a law guaranteeing the right to breastfeed has been broken, legal action has been taken.<ref name="Barsch_2006">{{cite news | last= Barsch | first= Sky | title= Woman alleges she was kicked off Burlington flight for breast-feeding | date= June 11, 2006 | publisher= Associated Press | url= http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,229390,00.html | accessdate= 2007-01-24 | deadurl= no | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070122232519/http://www.foxnews.com/story/0%2C2933%2C229390%2C00.html | archivedate= January 22, 2007 | df= }}</ref> Some companies have even apologised afterward.<ref name=legoland>{{cite news|title=Legoland Apologizes To Kelly Sabourin, Breastfeeding Mom Told To Move|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/02/03/legoland-kelly-sabourin_n_1253276.html|accessdate=28 September 2015|date=February 3, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150929005048/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/02/03/legoland-kelly-sabourin_n_1253276.html|archivedate=29 September 2015|df=}}</ref> One woman who was not allowed to breastfeed despite showing the [[Kentucky]] law that allows her the right,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncsl.org/research/health/breastfeeding-state-laws.aspx|title=Summary of Enacted Breastfeeding Legislation Kentucky|accessdate=21 February 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140210112805/http://www.ncsl.org/research/health/breastfeeding-state-laws.aspx|archivedate=10 February 2014|df=}}</ref> left but later organized several "nurse-in" protests in front of the restaurant and other public places.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kentucky.com/181/story/161782.html |title=Applebee's, woman in dispute over breast-feeding |accessdate=2009-12-17 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080101113120/http://www.kentucky.com/181/story/161782.html |archivedate=2008-01-01 |df= }}</ref>
In June 2007, Brooke Ryan was dining in a booth at the rear of an [[Applebee's]] restaurant when she began to breastfeed her seven-month-old son. Although she attempted to be discreet, another patron complained to the manager about [[indecent exposure]]. Both a waitress and the manager asked her to cover up. She handed him a copy of the [[Kentucky]] law that permitted public breastfeeding, but he would not relent. She opted to feed her son in her car, and later organized [[civil disobedience|"nurse-out" protests]] in front of the restaurant and other public locations.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pregnancyweightloss6.com/after-pregnancy-weight-loss/breastfeeding-protest-targets-restaurant-chain/ |title=Breastfeeding Protest Targets Restaurant Chain |date=10 September 2007 |work=Breastfeeding Protest Targets Restaurant Chain |accessdate=21 February 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140227175207/http://www.pregnancyweightloss6.com/after-pregnancy-weight-loss/breastfeeding-protest-targets-restaurant-chain/ |archivedate=27 February 2014 |df= }}</ref> Most U.S. states (49 as of September 2015) have laws clarifying a woman's right to breastfeed in public.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncsl.org/programs/health/breast50.htm |title=50 State Summary of Breastfeeding Laws |date=November 2008 |publisher=National Conference of State Legislatures |accessdate=7 January 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20090429231942/http://www.ncsl.org/programs/health/breast50.htm |archivedate=29 April 2009 |df= }}</ref>
In 2008 a woman in [[New Orleans]] put a tent over her truck at a street festival so she could nurse her daughter privately. She was cited by police for an "unauthorized booth" and removed from the street festival.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.momsbreastaurant.org/about_story.shtml|title=Mom's Breastaurant|work=momsbreastaurant.org|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120804221615/http://www.momsbreastaurant.org/about_story.shtml|archivedate=2012-08-04|df=}}</ref><ref>"Mom's Breastaurant", Catherine P. Businelle, ''Mothering'', January/February 2008, p. 62</ref><ref>"Milpitas woman creates retreat for nursing moms", Wes Bowers, ''Milpitas Post'', August 14, 2008, p. 38</ref>
=== Babytalk magazine cover === In 2006, the editors of U.S. ''[[Babytalk (magazine)|Babytalk]]'' magazine received many complaints from readers after the cover of the August issue depicted a baby nursing at a bare breast. Even though the model's nipple was not shown, readers—many of them mothers—wrote that the image was "gross". In a follow-up poll, one-quarter of 4,000 readers who responded thought the cover was negative. ''Babytalk'' editor Susan Kane commented, "There's a huge puritanical streak in Americans."<ref name="auto"/>
=== Mother & Baby magazine ===
In June, 2010, a deputy editor for the leading UK parenting magazine ''Mother & Baby'' set off a storm of protest when she described breastfeeding as "creepy." Kathryn Blundell told readers that she bottlefed her child from birth because, "I wanted my body back [and] to give my boobs at least a chance to stay on my chest rather than dangling around my stomach." She upset readers when she wrote about her breasts, "They're part of my sexuality, too – not just breasts, but fun bags. And when you have that attitude (and I admit I made no attempt to change it), seeing your teeny, tiny, innocent baby latching on where only a lover has been before feels, well, a little creepy." The anti-breastfeeding tone of her article prompted six complaints to the British [[Press Complaints Commission]] and set off considerable online debate. The magazine also received dozens of messages of support.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rock|first=Lucy|title=Breastfeeding is 'creepy', says parenting magazine|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2010/jun/27/breastfeeding-is-creepy-outrage|accessdate=25 November 2011|newspaper=The Observer|date=26 June 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224113042/http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2010/jun/27/breastfeeding-is-creepy-outrage|archivedate=24 December 2013|df=}}</ref>
=== Barbara Walters ===
In 2005 US television presenter [[Barbara Walters]] remarked on her talk show ''[[The View (U.S. TV series)|The View]]'' that she felt uncomfortable sitting next to a breastfeeding mother during a flight. Her comments upset some viewers who began organizing protests over the internet. A group of about 200 mothers staged a public "nurse in" where they breastfed their babies outside ABC's headquarters in New York.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/06/07/nyregion/07nurse.html|title='Lactivists' Taking Their Cause, and Their Babies, to the Streets|date=7 June 2005|work=The New York Times|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402165906/http://www.nytimes.com/2005/06/07/nyregion/07nurse.html|archivedate=2 April 2015|df=}}</ref>
=== Target store protest ===
In December, 2011, Michelle Hickman was breastfeeding her infant at the back of a Target store in Houston, Texas. Although covered, she was asked by two employees to move to a fitting room. Hickman said one of the employees told her, "You can get a ticket and be reported for indecent exposure." She reported the harassment on Facebook, and in response a number of mothers organized public "nurse-ins" at [[Target Corporation|Target]] stores across the United States in cities including Houston, [[Knoxville, Tennessee|Knoxville]], and Decatur, Illinois.<ref>{{cite news|title=Breastfeeding Moms Stage 'Nurse-In' Protest at Target Stores Worldwide|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2011/12/28/breastfeeding-moms-stage-nurse-in-protest-at-target-stores-worldwide/?test=latestnews#ixzz1htuFYsSp|accessdate=10 February 2012|newspaper=FoxNews|date=December 28, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120214112857/http://www.foxnews.com/us/2011/12/28/breastfeeding-moms-stage-nurse-in-protest-at-target-stores-worldwide/?test=latestnews#ixzz1htuFYsSp|archivedate=14 February 2012|df=}}</ref> [[Trace Gallagher]] on FoxNews reported on the protest, and female host of ''[[America Live]]'' [[Megyn Kelly]] commented, “You know, I got a lot of thoughts on this, Trace.” She explained, “Let me just put it this way: I used to feel a lot differently before I had babies and you’re breastfeeding; they need to be fed and then sometimes they don’t like the cover. And before you know it, you're Megyn Kelly and you’re showing your breasts to a whole plane.”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theblaze.com/stories/megyn-kelly-reveals-past-airplane-breastfeeding-flub-on-air/|title=Megyn Kelly Reveals Past Airplane Breastfeeding Flub On-Air|author=Jonathon M. Seidl|work=The Blaze|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120107134022/http://www.theblaze.com/stories/megyn-kelly-reveals-past-airplane-breastfeeding-flub-on-air/|archivedate=2012-01-07|df=}}</ref>
=== Claridge's hotel ===
In 2014 a waiter at [[Claridge's]] hotel in [[Mayfair, London]] asked Louise Burns to breastfeed under a cloth. Burns was told that it was hotel policy for mothers to cover up while breastfeeding. UK politician and broadcaster [[Nigel Farage]] spoke out in support of the hotel's right to have such a policy<ref name=Wintour-Mason>{{cite newspaper|title=Nigel Farage says breastfeeding women should sit in a corner|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2014/dec/05/nigel-farage-ukip-claridges-breastfeeding-mothers|newspaper=The Guardian|author1=Patrick Wintour|author2=Rowena Mason|date=5 December 2014}}</ref> but the [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]]'s office at [[10 Downing Street]] said it was "totally unacceptable for any women to be made to feel uncomfortable when breastfeeding in public". A group of about 25 mothers held a protest against the policy by breastfeeding outside the hotel.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-30359606 |title=Claridge's breastfeeding row: Protest by mothers |work=BBC News |date=6 December 2014 }}</ref> Claridge's subsequently denied that asking breastfeeding mothers to cover up was hotel policy<ref name=Wintour-Mason/> and said that breastfeeding mothers were welcome at the hotel, adding: "all we ask is that mothers are discreet towards other guests".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-30298382 |title=Claridge's says it welcomes breastfeeding after 'shroud' tweet |work=BBC News|date=2 December 2014 }}</ref>
=== Breastfeeding in uniform in the US military ===
In May 2012, two Air Force National Guard service members stationed at [[Fairchild Air Force Base]], Washington, participated in a breastfeeding awareness campaign hosted by the Mom2Mom of Fairchild Breastfeeding Support Group. Photographer Brynja Sigurdardottir, also a military spouse, staged and photographed Terran Echegoyen-McCabe and Christina Luna breastfeeding in uniform. Crystal Scott, the founder of Mom2Mom, said people thought the photograph was a disgrace to the uniform and compared their actions to defecating or urinating in uniform.<ref>{{cite journal | last = McFarlane | first = Megan D. | title = Breastfeeding as subversive: mothers, mammaries and the military | journal = [[International Feminist Journal of Politics]] | volume = 17 | issue = 2 | pages = 191–208 | publisher = [[Taylor and Francis]] | doi = 10.1080/14616742.2013.849967 | date = 2015 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/14616742.2013.849967 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> Some military personnel felt that it was impossible for a woman to maintain a professional military bearing while nursing in uniform.<ref name=forget/> But some active-duty veteran military members who are also mothers were more supportive, suggesting that the women enhanced the prestige of the military.<ref name="Weinstein">{{cite web|last=Weinstein|first=Adam|title=Mother of All Wars: The Battle to Breastfeed in Uniform|url=https://www.motherjones.com/mojo/2012/05/breastfeeding-military-uniform|publisher=Mother Jones|accessdate=25 May 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130423224313/https://www.motherjones.com/mojo/2012/05/breastfeeding-military-uniform|archivedate=23 April 2013|df=}}</ref> The photographs quickly went viral and were shared worldwide. To help reduce the controversy, Sigurdardottir removed the photos from her website and Facebook fan page. Her intention was to raise awareness and support for women who breastfeed, inside and outside of the military. When the controversy arose, the message was quickly lost among critics.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}
While the U.S. Air Force did not endorse the pictures, their commanding officer gave the women permission to be photographed in uniform while breastfeeding.<ref name=forget>{{cite web|title=Forget Breastfeeding in Public…What About in Uniform?|date=May 21, 2012|url=http://breastfeedingincombatboots.com/2012/05/forget-breastfeeding-publicwhat-about-uniform/|website=Breastfeeding in Combat Boots|accessdate=24 September 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925114323/http://breastfeedingincombatboots.com/2012/05/forget-breastfeeding-publicwhat-about-uniform/|archivedate=25 September 2015|df=}}</ref> The U.S. military protects women in uniform by allowing them to defer deployments for 4 to 12 months after childbirth for breastfeeding purposes. Breastfeeding service members are provided regular breaks to breastfeed or pump while on duty, and are provided with a comfortable and private place to do so.<ref name="Weinstein"/>
=== Facebook controversy ===
Facebook has [[Criticism of Facebook#Breastfeeding photos|been criticized]] for removing photos of mothers breastfeeding their children, citing offensive content in violation of the Facebook Terms of Service.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/lex-appeal-2-breastfeeding/id359323807?i=85336196&mt=2 |title=Episode 2: Breastfeeding and the Right to Go Topless |publisher=Lex Appeal |date=2010-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402105549/https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/lex-appeal-2-breastfeeding/id359323807?i=85336196&mt=2 |archivedate=2015-04-02 |df= }}</ref> Facebook claimed that these photos violated their decency code by showing an exposed breast, even when the baby covered the nipple. This action was described as hypocritical, since Facebook took several days to respond to calls to deactivate a paid advertisement for a dating service that used a photo of a topless model.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/web/facebook-mothers-outraged-at-breastfeeding-ban/2007/09/07/1188783470779.html | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | title=Facebook ban incurs 'lactivist' wrath | date=2007-09-07 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090221035037/http://www.smh.com.au/news/web/facebook-mothers-outraged-at-breastfeeding-ban/2007/09/07/1188783470779.html | archivedate=2009-02-21 | df= }}</ref>
The breastfeeding photos controversy continued following public protests and the growth in the online membership in the Facebook group titled "Hey, Facebook, breastfeeding is not obscene! (Official petition to Facebook)."<ref name="San Jose Mercury News">{{cite news|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_11321458|title=Protests mount over Facebook ban on breast-feeding photos; bigger turnout online than in Palo Alto|publisher=Mercury News|date=December 27, 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111117151220/http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_11321458|archivedate=November 17, 2011|df=}}</ref> In December 2011 Facebook removed photos of mothers breastfeeding and, after public criticism, restored them. The company said it had removed the photos because they violated the pornographic rules in the company's terms and conditions.<ref>{{cite news|last=McGinty|first=Bill|title=Facebook apologizes for removing breastfeeding photo|url=http://www.wcnc.com/home/Facebook-does-about-face-on-breast-feeding-photo-136442808.html|accessdate=February 17, 2012|newspaper=WCNC.COM|date=December 30, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120410065745/http://www.wcnc.com/home/Facebook-does-about-face-on-breast-feeding-photo-136442808.html|archivedate=April 10, 2012|df=}}</ref> During February, 2012, the company once again removed photos of mothers breastfeeding. Founders of a Facebook group "Respect the Breast" reported that "women say they are tired of people lashing out at what is natural and what they believe is healthy for their children."<ref>{{cite news|last=McGinty|first=Bill|title=Photos on breastfeeding Facebook page removed again|url=http://www.wcnc.com/news/health/Breastfeeding-photos-taken-down-off-Facebook-139464913.html|accessdate=17 February 2012|newspaper=WCNC.COM|date=February 16, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120410065749/http://www.wcnc.com/news/health/Breastfeeding-photos-taken-down-off-Facebook-139464913.html|archivedate=10 April 2012|df=}}</ref>
== See also == * [[History and culture of breastfeeding]] * [[Child's Right to Nurse Act]] * [[International Breastfeeding Symbol]] * [[Simple living]] * [[Women's Equality Day]]

== Further reading == * {{cite web | title = Breastfeeding state laws | url = http://www.ncsl.org/default.aspx?tabid=14389 | website = ncsl.org | publisher = National Conference of State Legislatures | date = 30 August 2016 }} * {{cite web | title = Breastfeeding in public from around the world | url = http://www.007b.com/public-breastfeeding-world.php | website = 007b.com | publisher = 007 Breasts }} - A collection of notes about attitudes towards public breastfeeding in different countries around the world. <!-- {{cite journal|url=|title=|doi=}} --> * {{cite journal|url=http://internationalbreastfeedingjournal.com/content/3/1/11|doi=10.1186/1746-4358-3-11|title=Got milk? Not in public!|year=2008|last1=Wolf|first1=Jacqueline H|journal=International Breastfeeding Journal|volume=3|issue=1|page=11|pmid=18680578|pmc=2518137}} * {{Cite journal|last1=Johnston-Robledo |first1=Ingrid |last2=Wares |first2=Stephanie |last3=Fricker |first3=Jessica |last4=Pasek |first4=Leigh|title=Indecent Exposure: Self-objectification and Young Women’s Attitudes Toward Breastfeeding | journal = [[Sex Roles (journal)|Sex Roles]] | volume = 56 | issue = 7–8 |pages= 429–437 | publisher = [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] | doi = 10.1007/s11199-007-9194-4 | date = April 2007 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s11199-007-9194-4 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} * {{Cite journal|last1=Johnston-Robledo |first1=Ingrid |last2=Fred |first2= Victoria |title= Self-Objectification and Lower Income Pregnant Women's Breastfeeding Attitudes | journal = [[Journal of Applied Social Psychology]] | volume = 38 | issue = 1 |pages= 1–21 | publisher = [[Wiley-Blackwell]] | doi = 10.1111/j.1559-1816.2008.00293.x | date = January 2008 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1559-1816.2008.00293.x | ref = harv | postscript = .}} * {{cite journal|title=Regional Variation in Public Opinion About Breastfeeding in the United States |doi=10.1177/0890334405278490|year=2005|last1=Hannan|first1=A.|journal=Journal of Human Lactation|volume=21|pages=284–288|pmid=16113017|last2=Li|first2=R|last3=Benton-Davis|first3=S|last4=Grummer-Strawn|first4=L|issue=3}} * {{cite journal | last = Barnes Cook | first = Amanda | title = Breastfeeding in public: disgust and discomfort in the bodiless public sphere | journal = [[Politics & Gender]] | volume = 12 | issue = 4 | pages = 677–699 | publisher = [[Cambridge University Press|Cambridge Journals]] | doi = 10.1017/S1743923X16000052 | date = December 2016 | url = https://doi.org/10.1017/S1743923X16000052 | ref = harv| postscript = .}}
