revision.text:
The '''Millennium Cohort Study''' is an ongoing longitudinal [[cohort study]] headquartered at the Naval Health Research Center in [[San Diego]], [[California]] and designed to evaluate any long-term [[health effect]]s of military service, including deployments.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Margaret A.K. Ryan |author2=Tyler C. Smith |author3=Besa Smith |author4=Paul Amoroso |author5=Edward J. Boyko |author6=Gregory C. Gray |author7=Gary D. Gackstetter |author8=James R. Riddle |author9=Timothy S. Wells |author10=Gia Gumbs |author11=Thomas E. Corbeil |author12=Tomoko I. Hooper |title=Millennium Cohort: enrollment begins a 21-year contribution to understanding the impact of military service |url=http://ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17208125?report=abstract |accessdate=2013-08-15 |publisher=Journal of Clinical Epidemiology |volume=60 |issue=2 |year=2007 |pages=181–191 |doi=10.1016/j.jclinepi.2006.05.009 |pmid=17208125 |journal=Journal of Clinical Epidemiology }}</ref> It is the largest population-based prospective health project in US military history,<ref>{{cite web |author=Naval Health Research Center |url=http://www.dcmilitary.com/journal/features/nhrc-launches-next-survey-cycle-of-largest-dod-population-based/article_0eb072f0-d680-5a59-893d-cf48eaf1cbbb.html |accessdate=2013-08-15 |title=NHRC Launches Next Survey Cycle of Largest DoD Population-Based Military Health Study |publisher=DCMilitary.com |date=2011-07-14 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Naval Health Research Center |url=http://www.med.navy.mil/sites/nmrc/documents/NHRC_Press_Release_MilCo_13Jun11.pdf |accessdate=2013-08-15 |title=The Largest DoD Population-Based Military Health Study Launched Next Survey Cycle, Hopes to Enroll Military Members and Spouses |publisher=Naval Health Research Center |date=2011-07-19 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author= Michel E. Kilpatrick |url=http://www.usmedicine.com/2010-issues/april-2010/what-we-can-learn-in-21-years/ |accessdate=2013-08-15 |title=What We Can Learn in 21 Years |publisher=Usmedicine.com |date=April 2010 |archiveurl=Archived by WebCite® at https://www.webcitation.org/60feOHCJO?url=http://www.usmedicine.com/articles/what-we-can-learn-in-21-years.html |archivedate=2011-08-03 |deadurl=no }}</ref> currently collecting data on over 200,000 enrolled participants. Investigators that conduct the Millennium Cohort Study include uniformed and non-uniformed scientists from the Army,<ref>{{cite web |author= Military Operational Medicine Research Program(MOMRP) |url=https://momrp.amedd.army.mil/gulf_war_index.html |title=Gulf War Illnesses Research Program (GWIRP) |publisher=Momrp.amedd.army.mil |date=2003-03-26 |accessdate=2013-08-15 }}</ref> Navy,<ref>{{cite web |author=Naval Health Research Center |url=https://www.med.navy.mil/sites/nhrc/research/mph/Pages/Millennium-Cohort-Program.aspx |title=Military Population Health - Millennium Cohort study |publisher=Med.navy.mil |date=1999-09-30 |accessdate=2013-08-15 }}</ref> Air Force,<ref>{{cite web |author=Navy Lt. Jennifer Cragg |url=http://archive.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=49909 |title=Military medical advancements benefit civilian health care |publisher=American Forces Press Service |date=2008-05-16 |accessdate=2013-08-15 }}</ref> [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs|Department of Veterans Affairs]]<ref>{{cite web |author=U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs |url=http://www.research.va.gov/news/research_highlights/va-dod020104.cfm%23.UB6Jd6go9Rw |title=VA, DoD Teaming Up to Track Health of Military Forces |publisher=Research.va.gov |date=2010-04-01 |accessdate=2013-08-15 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120805145559/http://www.research.va.gov/news/research_highlights/va-dod020104.cfm%23.UB6Jd6go9Rw |archivedate=2012-08-05 |df= }}</ref> and academic institutions.<ref>{{cite web |title=First Conference on Military Families Held |author1=Karen Bowman |author2=Cynthia Monticue |lastauthoramp=yes |date=2010-04-05 |url=http://news.usc.edu/#!/article/28086/First-Conference-on-Military-Families-Held |accessdate=2013-08-15}} </ref><ref>{{cite web |author=National Cancer Institute |url=http://epi.grants.cancer.gov/Consortia/members/millenium.html |title=Cohort Consortium Members - EGRP |publisher=Epi.grants.cancer.gov |date=2010-07-08 |accessdate=2013-08-15 }}</ref>[[File:MillenniumCohortStudyMLogoWithText.png.jpg|frame|right|border]]
== Origin == After the 1991 Gulf War, the [[United States Department of Defense]] recognized the need to collect prospective exposure and health information that may be associated with the long-term health of service members .<ref>{{cite web |author=Lyla M. Hernandez, Jane S. Durch, Dan G. Blazer II, and Isabel V. Hoverman, Editors; Committee on Measuring the Health of Gulf War Veterans, Institute of Medicine |url=http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=9636&page=R3 |title=Gulf War Veterans: Measuring Health |publisher=Nap.edu |year=1999 |accessdate=2013-08-15 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Office of the Special Assistant for Gulf War Illnesses, Medical Readiness, and Military Deployments |url=http://www.gulflink.osd.mil/medical/mvhcb_s08.htm |title=Lessons Learned And Recent Initiatives |publisher=Gulflink.osd.mil |date=1998-11-11 |accessdate=2013-08-15 }}</ref> The Millennium Cohort Study was designed to address that need. Pilot studies were conducted in 2000; by mid-2001, the Millennium Cohort Study's first enrollment period was launched, collecting baseline data from over 77,000 people.
== Overview == The most methodologically rigorous epidemiological study on American military personnel deployed to Iraq and Afghanistan <ref>http://www.sciencemag.org/content/336/6083/872.full.pdf?sid=6dd957c0-21f1-4610-940f-dccfc61b508e</ref> is funded by the [[United States Department of Defense|US Department of Defense]] ,<ref>{{cite web |author=Force Health Protection & Readiness |url=http://www.defense.gov/News/NewsArticle.aspx?ID=45902 |title=Millennium Cohort Study to Watch Military Health |publisher=American Forces Press Service |date=June 2001 |accessdate=2013-08-15 }}</ref> and supported by military, [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs]], and civilian researchers. Over 200,000 military personnel are members of the cohort. The Millennium Cohort Study began with a random sample of US Military members including active duty, Reserve, and [[National Guard of the United States|National Guard]] members from all services. Surveys are sent to this representative sample of US military personnel every three years through email and the United States Postal Service, requesting that they submit their data online or via the mail service. Approximately 25% of Millennium Cohort participants have left military service and the study will continue to follow all participants through their Active duty, Reserve, National Guard careers and civilian endeavors.
== Research == Prospective data analyses are underway to assess health outcomes including [[Suicide]] ,<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Cynthia A. LeardMann |author2=Teresa M. Powell |author3=Tyler C. Smith |author4=Michael R. Bell |author5=Besa Smith |author6=Edward J. Boyko |author7=Tomoko I. Hooper |author8=Gary D. Gackstetter |author9=Mark Ghamsary |author10=Charles W. Hoge |title=Risk Factors Associated With Suicide in Current and Former US Military Personnel |year=2013 |doi=10.1001/jama.2013.65164 |pmid=23925620 |publisher=Journal of American Medicine Association |pages=496–506 |volume=310 |issue=5 |url=http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1724276 |accessdate=2013-08-15 |journal=JAMA}}</ref> [[Posttraumatic stress disorder]],<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/bmj.b1273 |author=Cynthia A LeardMann, Tyler C Smith, Besa Smith, Timothy S Wells and Margaret A K Ryan for the Millennium Cohort Study Team |pmc=2671472 |title=Baseline self reported functional health and vulnerability to post-traumatic stress disorder after combat deployment: prospective US military cohort study |date=2008-12-19 |publisher=BMJ |pmid=19372117 |volume=338 |journal=BMJ |pages=b1273}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/bmj.39430.638241.AE |author=U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs |pmc=2244768 |title=New onset and persistent symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder self reported after deployment and combat exposures: prospective population based US military cohort study |date=2007-11-25 |pmid=18198395 |volume=336 |issue=7640 |journal=BMJ |pages=366–71}}</ref> depression,<ref>{{cite journal |author=Tyler C. Smith, Deborah L. Wingard, Margaret A.K. Ryan, Donna Kritz-Silverstein, Donald J. Slymen, and James F. Sallis, for the Millennium Cohort Study Team |pmc=2602934 |title=PTSD Prevalence, Associated Exposures, and Functional Health Outcomes in a Large, Population-Based Military Cohort |publisher=Association of Schools of Public Health |date=January 2009 |pmid=19413031 |volume=124 |issue=1 |journal=Public Health Rep |pages=90–102}}</ref> [[hypertension]], respiratory symptoms and illness,<ref>{{cite web |author=David Loebsack |date=2010-02-10 |title=Respiratory Conditions Investigated Among the Deployed |url=http://www.theveteransvoice.com/Respiratory-Conditions-Investigated-Among-the-Deployed.html |accessdate=2013-08-15 |publisher=Military Health System }}</ref> immune responses, chronic multi-symptom illness, CHD and CVD, and modifiable health behaviors such as smoking, alcohol use,<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Isabel G. Jacobson |author2=Margaret A. K. Ryan |author3=Tomoko I. Hooper |author4=Tyler C. Smith |author5=Paul J. Amoroso |author6=Edward J. Boyko |author7=Gary D. Gackstetter |author8=Timothy S. Wells |author9=Nicole S. Bell |title= Alcohol Use and Alcohol-Related Problems Before and After Military Combat Deployment |accessdate=2013-08-15 |date=2008-08-13 |doi=10.1001/jama.300.6.663 |pmid=18698065 |pmc=2680184 |publisher=Journal of American Medicine Association |pages=663–675 |volume=300 |issue=6 |url=http://jama.ama-assn.org/content/300/6/663.long |journal=JAMA}}</ref> sleep,<ref>{{cite journal |author=Amber D. Seelig, Isabel G. Jacobson, Besa Smith, Tomoko I. Hooper, Edward J. Boyko, Gary D. Gackstetter, Philip Gehrman, Carol A. Macera, Tyler C. Smith for the Millennium Cohort Study Team |pmc=2982731 |volume=33 |issue=12 |pages=1615–1622 |title=Sleep Patterns Before, During, and After Deployment to Iraq and Afghanistan |publisher=2010 Associated Professional Sleep Societies, LLC. |date=2010-12-01 |pmid=21120123 |journal=Sleep}}</ref> and physical activity that may be associated with deployment in support of the current wars.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Molly L Kelton, Cynthia A LeardMann, Besa Smith, Edward J Boyko, Tomoko I Hooper, Gary D Gackstetter, Paul D Bliese, Charles W Hoge, and Tyler C Smith, for the Millennium Cohort Study Team |volume=10 |page=94 |pmc=2967557 |title=Exploratory factor analysis of self-reported symptoms in a large, population-based military cohort |publisher=Kelton et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd. |doi=10.1186/1471-2288-10-94 |date=2010-10-15 |pmid=20950474 |journal=BMC Medical Research Methodology}}</ref> Currently, more than 60% of Millennium Cohort participants have deployed in support of the wars in [[Iraq War|Iraq]] and [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan]].
== Expansion == In 2011 the Millennium Cohort Study was expanded to include 10,000 spouses of Millennium Cohort members.The sub study, The [[Millennium Cohort Family Study]]'s<ref>{{cite web |author=Matt Pueschel |url=http://fhpr.dhhq.health.mil/press-newsroom/fhpr-news/archived_news/10-03-22/Millennium_Cohort_Study_Expanding_To_Include_Spouses_of_Service_Members.aspx?id=?id= |title=Millennium Cohort Study Expanding To Include Spouses of Service Members |publisher=Fhp.osd.mil |date=2010-12-29 |accessdate=2013-08-15}}</ref> goal is to gain a more complete understanding of the military experience and its resultant impact on the health and well-being of service members and their families.
==References== {{reflist}}
== Further reading == *Rush T, LeardMann CA, Crum-Cianflone NF. (2016). "'''Obesity and associated adverse health outcomes among US military members: Findings from the Millennium Cohort Study."''' Obesity (Silver Spring). 2016 Jul;24(7):1582-9. doi: 10.1002/oby.21513.{{PMID|27345964}} DOI:10.1002/oby.21513 *{{cite journal |pages=192–201 |doi=10.1016/j.jclinepi.2006.04.008 |title=Millennium Cohort: The 2001–2003 baseline prevalence of mental disorders in the U.S. Military |year=2007 |author=Riddle JR, Smith TC, Smith B, Corbeil TE, Engel CC, Wells TS, Hoge CW, Adkins J, Zamorski M, Blazer D for the Millennium Cohort Study Team. |journal=Journal of Clinical Epidemiology |volume=60 |issue=2 |pmid=17208126}} *{{cite journal |doi=10.1186/1471-2458-7-340 |title=The physical and mental health of a large military cohort: Baseline functional health status of the Millennium Cohort |authors =Tyler C Smith, Mark Zamorski, Besa Smith, James R Riddle, Cynthia A LeardMann, Timothy S Wells, Charles C Engel, Charles W Hoge, Joyce Adkins, Dan Blaze and the Millennium Cohort Study Team |year=2007 |journal=BMC Public Health |volume=7 |page=340 |pmid=18039387 |pmc=2212642}} *{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/bmj.39430.638241.AE |title=New onset and persistent symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder self reported after deployment and combat exposures: Prospective population based US military cohort study |year=2008 |authors=Tyler C Smith, Margaret A K Ryan, Deborah L Wingard, Donald J Slymen, James F Sallis, and Donna Kritz-Silverstein for the Millennium Cohort Study Team |journal=BMJ |volume=336 |issue=7640 |pages=366–71 |pmid=18198395 |pmc=2244768}}
== External links == * [http://www.millenniumcohort.org/ Official Millennium Cohort Study website] * [http://www.millenniumcohort.org/research/publications Millennium Cohort Study Publications] * [http://www.millenniumcohort.org/endorsements Millennium Cohort Endorsements] * [http://www.med.navy.mil/sites/nhrc/Pages/default.aspx Naval Health Research Center home page]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = National Farm Safety & Health Week |type = National |longtype = |image = |caption = |official_name = National Farm Safety & Health Week |nickname = |observedby = [[United States]] |begins = |ends = |date = Third week of September |celebrations = Agricultural & farming safety and health safety |duration = 1 week |frequency = Annual |relatedto = |observances = }}
'''National Farm Safety & Health Week''' is a week of commemoration, recognized annually on the third week of September in the United States.
==Origins== In 1944, President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] signed the first proclamation for [[Agricultural safety and health|farm safety]] due to the high injury rate in agriculture. Agriculture is one of the most hazardous industries with a death rate of 23.2 deaths per 100,000 workers annually according to U.S. [[Bureau of Labor Statistics]] in 2013.<ref name="extension">{{Cite web|url=http://www.extension.iastate.edu/article/farm-safety-and-health-week-sept-20-26|title=Farm Safety and Health Week Is Sept. 20-26 {{!}} Iowa State University Extension and Outreach|website=www.extension.iastate.edu|access-date=2016-10-17}}</ref> However, many injuries are preventable through education. Serious injuries and death can be prevented by cautiously approaching field adjustments or repairs, taking precautions to avoid slips and falls, making smart decisions while assigning tasks to youth, using and maintaining the slow moving vehicle emblem correctly, and retrofitting tractors with rollover structures.<ref name="extension" />
==History== In September 2015, [[Barack Obama|President Obama]] gave an official proclamation to accentuate the importance of agriculture for our society and economy as well as affirm farm safety and health programs "America's farmers and ranchers have played a critical role in shaping our progress and forging a better future for coming generations. Through centuries of hard work, they have supplied our Nation with products and services essential to the economic and physical well-being of our society. "Across our country, those who work on farms bolster our economy and nourish our people by providing what we need at a most human level, helping to uphold America's founding creed: Out of many, we are one. This week, let us recognize the steadfast dedication and commitment of agricultural producers and their families, and let us reaffirm our resolve to promote their health and safety."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2015/09/21/presidential-proclamation-national-farm-safety-and-health-week-2015|title=Presidential Proclamation -- National Farm Safety and Health Week, 2015|date=2015-09-18|newspaper=whitehouse.gov|access-date=2016-10-17}}</ref>
Over the years, the development and dissemination of National Farm Safety & Health Week materials shifted from the [[National Safety Council]] to National Education Center for Ag Safety (NECAS). NECAS is the agricultural partner for the [[National Safety Council]] and has been serving the agricultural family and business community since 1997.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://agsafety.osu.edu/newsletter/ag-safety-stat/september-2015/announcements/national-farm-safety-and-health-week|title=National Farm Safety and Health Week {{!}} Agricultural Safety & Health Program|website=agsafety.osu.edu|access-date=2016-10-17}}</ref> Each year they provide farmers with programs and materials to promote farmer safety and health.<ref>http://www.necasag.org/aboutnecas/nationalfarmsafetyandhealthweek2016/</ref>
==Observances== [[United States President|President]] [[Donald Trump]] [[Presidential proclamation|proclaimed]] ''National Farm Safety & Health Week'' on September 15, 2017.<ref>{{cite news|last1=[[White House Office of the Press Secretary|Office of the Press Secretary]]|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2017/09/18/president-donald-j-trump-proclaims-september-17-through-september-23-national-farm|title=President Donald J. Trump Proclaims September 17 through September 23, 2017, as National Farm Safety and Health Week|work=[[whitehouse.gov]]|publisher=[[White House]]|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|language=en|date=September 15, 2017|accessdate=September 27, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aad.arkansas.gov/national-farm-safety-and-health-week-highlighted-by-state-and-national-leaders|title=National Farm Safety and Health Week Highlighted by State and National Leaders|first=|last=|work=[[List of Arkansas state agencies#Boards and commissions|Arkansas Agriculture Department]]|publisher=[[Politics and government of Arkansas#Law and government|Arkansas Government]]|location=[[Little Rock]]|date=September 18, 2017|accessdate=September 27, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2017/09/21/2017-20377/national-farm-safety-and-health-week-2017|title=National Farm Safety and Health Week, 2017|work=[[Federal Register]]|publisher=[[National Archives and Records Administration]]|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|date=September 15, 2017|accessdate=September 27, 2017|archiveurl=https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/FR-2017-09-21/pdf/2017-20377.pdf|archivedate=September 21, 2017}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:National Farm Safety and Health Week}} [[Category:Agriculture in the United States]] [[Category:Occupational safety and health]]

{{orphan|date=January 2011}}
==History== '''Prion diseases''' comprise [[Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease]] (CJD), [[Gerstmann–Sträussler–Scheinker syndrome]], [[fatal familial insomnia]] and related disorders.<ref>Prion diseases of humans and animals: their causes and molecular basis. Collinge J. Annu Rev Neurosci. 2001;24:519-50.</ref> A specialist [[prion disease]] clinic was established by Professor John Collinge at [[St Mary's Hospital, London]], in 1997.<ref name="nationalprionclinic.org">http://www.nationalprionclinic.org</ref> This was designated the NHS National Prion Clinic (NPC) in March 2001 by the [[UK Department of Health]].<ref name=one>NHS to open CJD clinic. http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/1398210.stm</ref><ref name=two>CJD patients to receive specialist treatment at first dedicated clinic. https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/health-news/cjd-patients-to-receive-specialist-treatment-at-first-dedicated-clinic-674871.html</ref> In August 2004, following the relocation of the [[Medical Research Council (UK)|Medical Research Council]] (MRC) Prion Unit from [[Imperial College]] to [[University College London]] (UCL),<ref name="prion.ucl.ac.uk">http://www.prion.ucl.ac.uk</ref> the NPC relocated to the [[National Hospital for Neurology and Neurosurgery]] at [[Queen Square, London|Queen Square]],<ref name="uclh.nhs.uk">http://www.uclh.nhs.uk/NR/rdonlyres/213992ED-FC59-4E21-B8D8-A3B3B97FFE5A/0/NHNNbrochurefinal.pdf</ref> part of the [[University College London Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust]].<ref>http://www.uclh.nhs.uk/</ref> The NPC is closely integrated with the MRC Prion Unit, a relationship of fundamental importance to the missions of both organisations.<ref name="prion.ucl.ac.uk"/> The NPC receives UK-wide and international referrals of all forms of suspected CJD or other prion diseases.<ref name="uclh.nhs.uk"/> It is internationally unique and has developed considerable experience in the clinical management of prion disease.<ref name="uclh.nhs.uk"/>
In addition to providing a national [[National Health Service|NHS]] centre of expertise for the management of all forms of CJD and other prion diseases, the clinic was established to facilitate research in both [[diagnostics]] and [[therapeutics]] including the organisation of [[clinical trial]]s.<ref name="ReferenceA">Collinge J, Gorham M, Hudson F, Kennedy A, Keogh G, Pal S, Rossor M, Rudge P, Siddique D, Spyer M, Thomas D, Walker S, Webb T, Wroe S, and Darbyshire J. A partially randomised patient preference trial to assess the safety and activity of quinacrine in human prion disease: the PRION-1 trial. Lancet Neurology. 2009</ref> The Health Services Director at the [[NHS Executive]] wrote to all UK hospitals to inform them of the clinic, and encourage referral to it.<ref>Chief Executive's Bulletin (2001). http://www.publications.doh.gov.uk/cebulletin22march.htm 2001</ref> The clinic liaises closely with the National CJD Surveillance Unit in [[Edinburgh]], [[Scotland]] (NCJDSU) to ensure that both centres are aware of all UK prion disease patients.<ref>http://www.dh.gov.uk/en/Publicationsandstatistics/Lettersandcirculars/Dearcolleagueletters/DH_4085464</ref>
==Referrals and staff== Aside from patients with Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease and other prion diseases, referrals are welcome of healthy but at-risk individuals from families with inherited prion disease.<ref name="nationalprionclinic.org"/> With some of these large pedigrees a clinical relationship has been fostered for around two decades since [[mutation]]s in the [[prion protein]] gene and their use in diagnosis and [[genetic counseling]] were first reported from 1989.<ref>Collinge J, Harding AE, Owen F, Poulter M, Lofthouse R, Boughey AM, Shah T, Crow TJ. Diagnosis of Gerstmann–Straussler syndrome in familial dementia with prion protein gene analysis. Lancet 1989; 2: 15-7</ref> Through collaboration with the [[UK Health Protection Agency]] referrals are received from individuals at risk of variant Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease through [[blood transfusion]].<ref>http://www.dh.gov.uk/en/Publicationsandstatistics/Publications/PublicationsPolicyAndGuidance/DH_073486</ref>
In 2010 the clinic staff comprised consultant [[neurologist]]s Professor John Collinge and Drs Simon Mead and Peter Rudge and consultant [[Neuroradiology|neuro-radiologist]] Harpreet Hyare. Permanent NHS staff include Michele Gorham, a consultant nurse; and a clinical counsellor; with part-time input from a senior [[Clinical psychology|clinical psychologist]].<ref name="nationalprionclinic.org"/>
==The objectives of the NPC== * To provide inpatient and outpatient services for the comprehensive assessment of all suspected CJD and other prion disease (sporadic, acquired and inherited). The service includes rapid clinical assessment and diagnosis including, [[neuroimaging]], [[neuropsychology]], [[neurophysiology]], [[molecular genetics]], cerebral and tonsil [[biopsy]] (including [[biochemical analysis]] of prion strain type), CSF markers and the co-ordination of subsequent management of patients and their families, in liaison with local [[healthcare]] professionals. * Information, advice, support and [[counselling]] for patients and their families, both during investigation, on diagnosis, and long term follow up, working closely with and provide information and support for professionals working with registered patients in their local area. * Advice and support from a [[clinical nurse specialist]], counsellor and consultant staff for patients, families, carers and health professionals including a telephone help-line and email advice. Close liaison with the principal UK patient [[support group]]s is critical: particularly the CJD Support Network.<ref>http://www.cjdsupport.net</ref> * Provide an internationally recognized centre of expertise for prion disease diagnosis and staff training. Also helping to develop national standards for patient management and [[infection control]] in hospitals, and provide clinical and scientific input to the activities of several government appointed national committees. * To provide the infrastructure to enable UK clinical trials in prion disease and to facilitate the clinical and other research of the MRC Prion Unit and its collaborators. In 2007 the NPC completed the first large national clinical trial in prion disease, the PRION-1 trial of the experimental prion therapeutic [[quinacrine]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Currently (2010) the NPC is recruiting into the National Prion Monitoring Cohort study which aims to help optimise future clinical trials.<ref name="nationalprionclinic.org"/>
== References == {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:Medical and health organisations based in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Prions]]

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=January 2008}} A '''plague pit''' is the informal term used to refer to [[mass grave]]s in which victims of the [[Black Death]] were buried. The term is most often used to describe pits located in [[Great Britain]], but can be applied to any place where [[bubonic plague]] victims were buried.
==Origin== The plague which swept across [[China]], [[Middle East]], and [[Europe]] in the 14th century is estimated to have killed between one-third and two-thirds of [[Medieval demography|Europe's population]].<ref name="barry">Stéphane Barry and Norbert Gualde, "The Greatest Epidemic of History" ("La plus grande épidémie de l'histoire", in ''[[L'Histoire]]'' n° 310, June 2006, pp.45-46, say "between one-third and two-thirds"; [[Robert Gottfried]] (1983). "Black Death" in ''[[Dictionary of the Middle Ages]]'', volume 2, pp.257-67, says "between 25 and 45 percent".</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://history.boisestate.edu/westciv/plague/15.shtml |title=Population Loss |publisher=History.boisestate.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-10-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207081157/http://history.boisestate.edu/westciv/plague/15.shtml |archivedate=2009-02-07 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www3.iath.virginia.edu/osheim/plaguein.html |title=Plague and Public Health in Renaissance Europe |publisher=.iath.virginia.edu |date=1994-10-28 |accessdate=2011-10-27}}</ref> Disposal of the bodies of those who died presented huge problems for the authorities, and eventually the normal patterns of burial and funerary observance broke down.
==Major plague outbreaks== Plague pits were used especially often during major plague outbreaks, such as the [[Great Plague of London|London epidemic of 1665]]. During these times, graveyards rapidly filled, and such graves became available only to wealthy people. Parishes became strained; one example, the records of [[St Bride's Church]] on [[Fleet Street]] during the London 1665 plague, shows typical methods employed by the parishes.
In 1665, the total number of deaths in the parish rose to five and a half times their normal number, with 2,111 deaths overall and 1,427 attributed to plague.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.history.ac.uk/cmh/epiharding.html |title=Burial of the plague dead in early modern London |publisher=History.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-10-27}}</ref>
==Controversy regarding Black Death pathogen == Some scientists have put forward the idea that the Black Death was not caused by ''[[Yersinia pestis]]'' as some have thought, and some evidence of this has been found in plague pits, where the pathogens of other diseases, such as [[anthrax]], have been discovered.
However the screening of over 100 skeletal remains from Black Death victims buried in London's [[East Smithfield]] plague pit points to ''Yersinia pestis'' as the cause.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.nature.com/news/2011/10/black_death.html|title=Black Death plague pit produces first ancient bacterial genome : News blog|website=blogs.nature.com|date=12 October 2011 |first=Ewen|last=Callaway|access-date=2016-09-12}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==See also== * [[Mary King's Close]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Plague Pit}} [[Category:Epidemiology]] [[Category:Cemeteries]] [[Category:Death in the United Kingdom]]

{{Infobox person | name = Sanjoy Ghose | image = Image file of Sanjoy Ghose.jpg | alt = | caption = Sanjoy Ghose as he would have appeared in 1997 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date |df=yes|1959|12|07}} | birth_place = Nagpur, Maharashtra | death_date = {{Death date |df=yes|1997|07|04|}} | death_place = Majuli, Assam | nationality = Indian | other_names = JOY | known_for = Setting up Non Government Organisations working in North India | occupation = Rural community health activist, development media }}
'''Sanjoy Ghose''' ({{lang-bn| সঞ্জয় ঘোষ}}) (7 December 1959 – 4 July 1997) was an [[India]]n rural development activist known for his pioneering contributions to community health and development media. He is believed to have been killed by [[United Liberation Front of Asom]] (ULFA) militants in the river island of [[Majuli]] on the [[Brahmaputra]] river around 4 July 1997.
==Biography==
===Early life=== Born in [[Nagpur]], Ghose spent his formative years and his adolescence in [[Mumbai]], Maharashtra. He belonged to a well known Bengali family.<ref>{{cite news | title =Sanjay Ghose killing a mistake: Ulfa – Rift in outfit ahead of Feb. 10 peace talks | quote =Ghose, who was brought up in Mumbai and later settled in Delhi, was related to several among the Bengali who’s who. Former Doordarshan chief Bhaskar Ghose was an uncle, while former Supreme Court judge Ruma Pal and diplomat Arundhati Ghose were his aunts. | newspaper =The Telegraph, Calcutta,India | date =6 February 2011 | url =http://www.telegraphindia.com/1110206/jsp/frontpage/story_13543113.jsp }}</ref> Bhaskar Ghose, erstwhile Director General of [[Doordarshan]], the Indian public television network, is his uncle. His aunts are [[Ruma Pal]] a former Supreme Court judge, [[Arundhati Ghose]], former diplomat and India's permanent representative to the United Nations during the 1990s,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.satp.org/satporgtp/publication/faultlines/volume1/Fault1-Arundhtext.htm |title=Terrorists, Human Rights and the United Nations |publisher=Satp.org |date= |accessdate=28 March 2013}}</ref> and the journalist Usha Rai.<ref>{{cite news | author =Nava Thakuria | title =Kamala Saikia memorial lecture by Usha Rai | quote =My nephew Sanjoy Ghose, a highly committed social activist, was killed by ULFA in 1997. I was then working with Hindustan Times and when he told me about how ULFA had threatened him if he did not back off from his work in Majuli Island and leave Assam, I decided to come for the meeting where the people of Majuli and the local leaders were to come out in a show of support for him. It was a tense meeting and despite efforts to break the meeting there was a solid show of support from the community he was working for. I wrote about this meeting and the threat to NGOs working in the North East in the hope that ULFA would be aware that the media was watching it. The story was front page anchor in Hindustan Times, Delhi. Buoyed by the support he received, Sanjoy decided to stay on and that was a mistake. The very next month he was abducted and killed. | newspaper =Assam Times | year = | date =10 August 2010 | url =http://www.assamtimes.org/knowledge-development/4231.html }}{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> His mother, Vijaya Ghose, is the editor of the Limca Book of records<ref>{{cite news | author =Roshni Nair | title =Meeting Vijaya Ghose - the record keeper| quote =But her worst blow had come 10 years earlier in 1997, when son Sanjoy Ghose, a social worker who started Bikaner's URMUL Trust, was abducted and killed by ULFA militants in Majuli, Assam. His body was never found. Ghose's husband, who never recovered from the tragedy, passed away last year. | newspaper = dna| date = 17 May 1915| url = http://www.dnaindia.com/lifestyle/report-the-record-keeper-2086474|access-date= 2015-07-17 }}</ref> He was educated at the [[Cathedral and John Connon School]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Ajit |first1=Chaudhuri |year=2007 |title=Sanjoy Ghose: Ten Years After |journal=Network |volume=11 |issue=2 |pages= |publisher=Institute of Rural Management, Anand |url=https://www.irma.ac.in/inetwork/networkpastissuesdetail.php?issid=29 |accessdate=21 August 2013 }}</ref> He was the president of his school wing of the Interact club: which is the [[Rotary International]] sponsored service club for young people aged 12 to 18.His experiences of social work, as a school boy, through the Interact club, changed his life priorities, and set the course for his life. <ref>{{cite journal |last1=Mirai |first1=Chatterjee |year=2009 |title=Looking back, looking forward |journal=The X-Cathedralite |volume= |issue= |pages=16 |publisher=The Cathedral and John Canoon School alumni |url=http://www.catalumni.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/AlumniMag2009_2.pdf |accessdate= 21 August 2013}}</ref> His father recalls, "As a school going boy he spent two nights in a Bombay (presently Mumbai) slum in torrential rain just to get a feel of the real problems that plague slums." <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.charkha.org/html/founder.html |title=Our Founder |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=http://www.charkha.org/ |publisher= |accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> After school, he was educated at a liberal arts college, [[Elphinstone College]] located in [[Mumbai]]. Apart from graduating in rural development and law with college and university honours, he also edited the college magazine, ran the English literature club, and won [[University of Mumbai]] competitions for quizzing and debating. He was also active in the [[National Service Scheme]] – taking his fellow students to remote tribal villages in the hilly tracts abutting the [[Western Ghats]] in [[Thane district]]- to experience first hand the poverty and exploitation of the tribal communities. <ref>{{cite book |title=Sanjoy's Assam: Dairies and Writings of Sanjoy Ghose ; Edited and with an Afterword by Sumita Ghose|publisher=Penguin Books India |location=New Delhi, India |edition=|first=Sanjoy | last= Ghose|volume=|page=47,48 |chapter=Two |url=https://www.amazon.com/Sanjoys-Assam-Sumita-Ghose/dp/0140278559|isbn=0140278559}}</ref> <ref>{{cite book |last=Sanjoy |first=Ghose |editor-first=Sumita |editor-last=Ghosh |title= Sanjoy's Assam: Dairies and Writings of Sanjoy Ghose ; Edited and with an Afterword by Sumita Ghose|publisher=Penguin Books India |year=1998|pages=47, 48 |chapter= 2|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=oIwbNz3WwRsC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=Elphinstone%20college&f=false|isbn= 9780140278552}}</ref>
In 1980, he chose to join the then unknown [[Institute of Rural Management, Anand]] (IRMA) in its very first batch. He had confirmed admissions to all the three then existing IIMs, ( [[Indian Institute of Management Ahmedabad|Indian Institute of Management]] ) – Ahmedabad, Bangalore and Calcutta. Joining the prestigious IIM opened the way to very well paying corporate careers. He chose the then unknown IRMA over the known IIMs, in keeping with his personal commitment to work for the poorest of the poor.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sanjoy |first=Ghose |editor-first=Sumita |editor-last=Ghosh |title= Sanjoy's Assam: Dairies and Writings of Sanjoy Ghose ; Edited and with an Afterword by Sumita Ghose|publisher=Penguin Books India|year=1998|pages=52 |chapter= 2|url =https://books.google.com/books?id=oIwbNz3WwRsC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |isbn= 9780140278552}}</ref>
Dr.Srikanth Sambrani, the first director of IRMA, remembered the selection interview, in an Indian Express article, dated 12 August 1997, thus – "I first met him in 1980, when conducting admissions interviews for the Institute of Rural Management at Anand. We were highly impressed by his paper qualifications. He walked into our small room, all 5 ft 5 in of him held like the fearless bantam he undoubtedly was. But since he had applied to IIM Ahmedabad also, we thought we would lose him. We spent an hour discussing the relative merits of IIMA and IRMA. When he turned down IIMA, it was a coup for us."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.expressindia.com/news/ie/daily/19970812/22450383.html |title=Sanjoy Ghose: Joy and outrage |publisher=Expressindia.com |date=12 August 1997 |accessdate=27 September 2010}}</ref>
===Career=== After his post graduation with very good grades from IRMA, in 1982, he chose to work in a small rural development trust, [[Tribhuvandas Foundation]], in Anand, Kheda district, over much more visible and better paying jobs with Government sponsored milk cooperative federations. In Tribhuvandas Foundation, he catalysed its growth from a small family run trust, to working in hundred odd villages, hiring professional rural medical doctors, and extension staff.
After two years with Tribhuvandas foundation, he won the INLAKs foundation scholarship for a MSc degree in economics from [[St Anne's College, Oxford]] in 1984.<ref name="Oxford University Gazette">{{cite web |first= |last= |authorlink= |title=OBITUARIES- St.Anne's college |url=http://www.ox.ac.uk/gazette/1997-8/weekly/150198/coll.htm#5Ref |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020223042025/http://www.ox.ac.uk/gazette/1997-8/weekly/150198/coll.htm#5Ref|work= |publisher= |location= |page= |pages= |doi= |date=15 January 1998 |month= |year= |archivedate=2002-02-23|accessdate=7 December 2012 |dead-url=yes|quote=SANJOY GHOSE; MSc student 1984–5. Aged 39. }}</ref> After Oxford, he decided to return to rural India. He set up the URMUL Rural Health and Development Trust — in the desert district of Bikaner in Rajasthan.(1986). While working with URMUL, he won the Hubert Humphrey fellowship — and spent a year with the prestigious [[Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health]] in the year 1988–89. Working with the sick of the poorest of the poor, told on his personal health. He contracted tuberculosis, while collecting sputum for testing, from potential TB patients. After establishing URMUL Rural Health and Development Trust as a mainstream NGO in Rajasthan, he handed over the organisation to a successor, and shifted to Delhi. This was an unprecedented decision for Indian voluntary agencies — as the founders usually hang on to their leadership position till they die.
Sanjoy Ghose wrote extensively about his grassroot experiences with the URMUL Trust in Lunkaransar Village in Bikaner.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Ghose |first1=Sanjoy |year=1995 |title=Settlement in the Indira Gandhi canal command: a new perspective |journal=Land Reforms in India |volume= |issue= |pages=176–182 |publisher=Sage Publications |url=http://www.cwds.ac.in/library/services/26.Land_Rights.pdf |accessdate=7 December 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304053012/http://www.cwds.ac.in/library/services/26.Land_Rights.pdf |archive-date=4 March 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The Indian Express, a leading national daily, used his writings to launched a successful monthly column named 'Village Voice'. The "action experiment" of tapping the power of the mainstream middle class urban English media to reflect unheard rural voices spoken in local languages, grounded in very local realities, got a measure of success.
Recognizing the potential of writing in mainstream media to highlight rural development issues and catalyse change, Sanjoy conceived of CHARKHA. CHARKHA appears to have been initiated to exploit the legitimate opportunities available in the national media for influencing policies related to rural development. It also addressed the concern that such a massive task, required more support than his single voice. His discussions with senior media persons from the national dailies seemed to suggest that an organisation dedicated to development communication could work. CHARKHA in a sense was an attempt to "institutionalize" the success of the "Village voice" experience — and broaden the scope to bring in more writing talent and different geographies. On 24 October 1994, CHARKHA was formally initiated in New Delhi- with the goal of spinning action into words.Its formal vision is "To contribute towards building a harmonious, inclusive society empowered by knowledge."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charkha.org/html/genesis.html |title=Genesis |publisher=Charkha.org |date=24 October 1994 |accessdate=27 September 2010}}</ref>
Sanjoy appeared to have been a firm believer in the philosophy of [[Reflective practice]]. He wrote and published extensively, analytic pieces on rural development- which would have incorporated insights from his own personal experiences as a catalyst for rural change .<ref>{{cite book |last= Ghose |first=Sanjoy |authorlink= |title=Voices from the Field: A Symposium on People's Experiences with the Development Process |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_lijPgAACAAJ&dq=Sanjoy+Ghose&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_9bXUcnNAsGkrQehooHABg&ved=0CFMQ6AEwBw |accessdate=6 July 2013 |year=1995 |publisher=Singh |location= |isbn= |page=}}</ref> The [[World Bank]] had also published one such paper.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Nagle | first1=William| last2= Ghose|first2=Sanjoy |title=Community Participation in World Bank Supported Projects Issue 8 of Strategic planning and review discussion paper |publisher=World Bank Strategic Planning and Review Department, Policy Research and External Affairs, |year=1990 |pages=28 |url =http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/34607585?selectedversion=NBD8810892}}</ref>
After launching CHARKHA, he decided to work in the insurgent prone Upper Assam, specifically in Majuli island on the Brahmaputra. His father recollected the family discussions around this decision. " When we were dissuading Sanjoy from going to the terrorism-ridden [[Assam]]", he replied, "then whose son will you send ?"<ref>{{cite news | author =Sangeeta Singh |title= Shankar Ghose He is passionate about connecting the poor with mainstream media | quote =He speaks passionately about Charkha’s activities, and about his son, even as his tea gets cold. It isn’t an easy conversation. The pain of talking about Sanjoy in the past tense, and the persistent guilt that he could not stop him from going to the North-East are palpable. Charkha’s website describes Ghose trying to dissuade his son from visiting Assam only for Sanjoy to ask: “Then, whose son will you send?”. | newspaper =Live Mint and Wall Street Journal | date =17 September 2007 | url =http://www.livemint.com/Companies/KAXIfL2WwJMKOMKfck5doM/Shankar-Ghose--He-is-passionate-about-connecting-the-poor-w.html }}</ref>
[[File:Sanjoy Ghose with his team of social workers in Majuli island.jpg|thumb|right|Sanjoy Ghose with his team of social workers in Majuli island.]] Through the sponsorship of Association of Voluntary Agencies for Rurul Development, North East (AVARD-NE) Sanjoy and seven colleagues set up base in Majuli island on the [[Brahmaputra]] river in April 1996. The island faced annual flooding and erosion of land. The island had shrunk by around 500 square kilometres in the last twenty years. Around February 1997, he and his team mobilised around 30,000 human days of voluntary labour (shram dhan). An experimental stretch of 1.7 kilometres of land was protected from erosion, by building embankments: using only local resources and their knowledge. The following year this protected stretch of the island survived the floods.<ref>{{cite news | author =Chetna Verma | title =Majuli remembers Sanjoy Ghose a decade and half later | quote =The turning point came in February 1997, when more than 30,000-man-days of labour were volunteered by the community, and an experimental stretch of 1.7 kilometers was protected from erosion using local wisdom and resources. The following year, this protected stretch of the island survived the floods, raising hopes and sending ripples of triumph through the people. | newspaper =ANI News | date =4 July 2012 | url =http://www.aninews.in/newsdetail2/story60761/Majuli-remembers-Sanjoy-Ghose-a-decade-and-half-later.html | access-date =7 December 2012 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20120707010651/http://www.aninews.in/newsdetail2/story60761/majuli-remembers-sanjoy-ghose-a-decade-and-half-later.html | archive-date =7 July 2012 | dead-url =yes | df =dmy-all }}</ref> Sanjoy, in this short time, had also diversified the social activities in Majuli: around health (malaria prevention),livelihoods (design, and manufacturing of bamboo and woven products), and education (village libraries).
It appears that by doing so, Sanjoy and his group had displeased a powerful local Government works contractor lobby: which also provided patronage to the [[United Liberation Front of Assam]] (ULFA). When posters were put up by presumably this contractor lobby, which would have lost its annual lucrative contracts for "flood protection": many locals participated in a public meeting on 1 June 1997, to express solidarity with the constructive work done. The local police offered Sanjoy protection, in view of the public threats issued by ULFA. Sanjoy however refused this, in tune with his personal beliefs that "local people are my best protection". ULFA abducted Sanjoy on 4 July 1997. <ref>{{cite news | author =Deepti Priya Mehrotra | title =The man who saw tomorrow | quote =The group mobilised people to build embankments: local people contributed 30,000 person-days of labour to protect an experimental stretch of 1.7 km of the island’s banks. In doing so, they displeased a powerful contractor lobby that provided patronage to ulfa .When posters came up asking avard-ne to leave Assam, many locals participated in a public meeting in solidarity with the constructive work being done. This was on June 1, 1997. The group had already engaged in flood relief and malaria prevention, design and production of weaving and bamboo crafts; it had also set up village libraries. The police offered him protection but Sanjoy refused, saying people were his protection. Soon after, he was abducted. Sanjoy vanished. | newspaper =Tehelka | date =29 January 2005 | url =http://archive.tehelka.com/story_main10.asp?filename=Cr012905the_man_who.asp | access-date =15 January 2013 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20160304030347/http://archive.tehelka.com/story_main10.asp?filename=Cr012905the_man_who.asp | archive-date =4 March 2016 | dead-url =yes | df =dmy-all }}</ref> Some of Sanjoy's written work, was put together and was released as a book by Penguin Books in 1998: titled "Sanjoy's Assam: diaries and writings of Sanjoy Ghose"<ref>{{cite book |title=Sanjoy's Assam: diaries and writings of Sanjoy Ghose|publisher= Penguin Books |location= Delhi |edition=first|first=Sanjoy | last= Ghose|volume=|page= |chapter= |url=|isbn=9780140278552}}</ref>
==Death == A newspaper article in the Deccan Herald on 9 February 2009 claimed that "(Ghose) had been killed a day after he was abducted by ULFA cadres on July four, 1997, and his body, which was never found, was thrown into the swirling waters of the Brahmaputra. The killing,... was carried out by local cadre even before the top leadership could convey to them the message not to harm him to avoid possible international repercussions."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://utpalborpujari.wordpress.com/2009/02/09/how-sanjoy-ghose-exactly-died/ |title=How Sanjoy Ghose exactly died? « Utpal Borpujari |publisher=Utpalborpujari.wordpress.com |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=27 September 2010}}</ref> Confirming that the death was at the hands of local ULFA terrorists,the ULFA leader, [[Paresh Baruah]] stated in an interview that "there was no instruction to kill Sanjoy Ghosh".<ref>{{cite news | author = Sangeeta Barooah Pisharoty| title =Portrait of anonymity| quote =He talked about Sanjoy Ghose’s murder affecting ULFA’s international reputation. Baruah told me there was no instruction to kill Sanjoy Ghosh. He was picked up on suspicion of being close to the Indian intelligence. He said the ULFA leaders were at Geneva when the controversy erupted in 1997. Their plan was to drum up international support through meetings with diplomats from 10 countries. But Arundhati Ghosh, Sanjoy’s aunt and a Foreign Service official, campaigned against the ULFA. She was successful and all ULFA top functionaries had to duck for cover and leave Europe.| newspaper = The Hindu| date =April 15, 2015 | url =http://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/portrait-of-anonymity/article7105031.ece |accessdate= 16 July 2015 }}</ref> The [[Central Bureau of Investigation]], which had been entrusted with the investigations, of the murder of Sanjoy Ghose, had filed chargesheets against 11 ULFA militants. <ref>{{cite news | title =CBI may take Ulfa cadre in remand | quote =The central agency, after investigation, had filed chargesheets against 11 Ulfa militants, namely Ulfa C-in-C Paresh Boruah, Phatik Hatimota, Siraj Boruah, Arun Boruah, Mridul Hazarika, Amrit Dutta, Babu Saikia, Phani Neog, Kania Hazarika, Pradip Boruah and Anjan Boruah. Among them Siraj, Arun, Mridul, Amrit and Babu were killed in encounter and Phani and Kania are now in jail. | newspaper =Times of India | year = | date =November 28, 2011 | url =http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-11-28/guwahati/30449461_1_ulfa-militants-majuli-island-remand }}</ref> <ref>{{cite news | author =Samudra Gupta Kashyap | title =anjoy Ghose murder accused arrested | quote =Hatimota was among 11 ULFA militants named in a CBI chargesheet filed before the special court here on June 16, 1999.Ghose, secretary of well-known NGO called AVARD-NE, was working on a rural development project in Majuli island for a couple of years when he apparently invited the wrath of a militant-contractor nexus that was allegedly involved in siphoning off funds meant for developmental works in the river island. | newspaper =The Indian Express | year = | date =26 November 2011 | url =http://www.indianexpress.com/news/Sanjoy-Ghose-murder-accused-arrested/880734/ }}</ref> <ref>{{cite news | title =Ulfa man in cop custody – Sanjoy Ghose murder accused produced in court | quote =Hatimota is among 11 Ulfa militants, including the outfit’s commander-in-chief Paresh Barua, who were convicted in the Sanjoy Ghose abduction and killing case. The CBI, which probed the killing of the social worker in 1997, had filed chargesheets against 11 cadres of the outfit. | newspaper =The Telegraph, Calcutta,India | year = | date = 27 November 2011 | url =http://www.telegraphindia.com/1111127/jsp/northeast/story_14802729.jsp }}</ref> The local ULFA leader, Amrit Datta, who was accused of masterminding the kidnap and murder of Sanjoy Ghose was killed in a joint operation by the Central Reserve Police Force, and the local police in a shootout in the evening of 19 July 2008 in Majuli. <ref>{{cite news | author =Press Trust of India | title =ULFA leader behind Sanjoy Ghosh’s death shot dead| quote =Hardcore ULFA leader Amrit Dutta, carrying a reward of Rs 3 lakh on his head for the kidnap and killing of NGO activist Sanjoy Ghosh, was killed in an encounter with the police and CRPF at Majuli in Assam on Saturday. Police sources said the ULFA leader was killed in the encounter at Katonihati Jurbil under the Jengraimukh police station in the world's largest river island at around 7 pm.A joint team of the police and CRPF received a tip-off that Dutta and two other militants had taken shelter in a house in the area. The police surrounded it and asked the militants to surrender. The militants opened fire on the security personnel who retaliated, killing Dutta. The other two managed to escape.Ghosh, who headed the NGO AVARD-NE, was kidnapped by ULFA in July 1997 from Bongaon area of Majuli and was subsequently killed, though his body was never recovered. According to intelligence reports, Dutta was based in Majuli and was involved in extortion and recruitment for the outfit | newspaper =The Indian Express| date = 20 July 2008| url =http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/ulfa-leader-behind-sanjoy-ghosh-s-death-shot-dead/337866/ |access-date= 4 July 2016 }}</ref> <ref>{{cite news | author = | title =Sanjoy murder accused killed | quote =Amrit Dutta, one of the accused in the kidnapping and murder of social activist Sanjoy Ghose, was killed in a joint operation by police and CRPF in Majuli this evening. orhat police confirmed that Dutta was killed in the encounter at Jorabeel Katoniati, a remote village under Garmur police station in Majuli. Details are awaited, they said.| newspaper = The Telegraph-Calcutta| date = 20 July 2008| url =http://www.telegraphindia.com/1080720/jsp/northeast/story_9574303.jsp |access-date= 4 July 2016}}</ref>
[[Arabinda Rajkhowa]], the Chairman of ULFA, publicly apologised at Majuli for the killing of Sanjoy Ghose, as per news reports of June 2011. His widow, Mrs. Schumita Ghose, responded, "Only the Almighty has the power to forgive. I am just a human being and I want justice to be done."<ref>{{cite news | author =SUDIPTA BHATTACHARJEE | title = THE PRICE OF PARDON -saying sorry | quote =Two days later, its chairman, Arabinda Rajkhowa, publicly apologized at Majuli for the killing of the social worker, Sanjoy Ghose, in 1997. While an apology is the key to healing wounds and injustices, what distinguishes the Ulfa’s apologies from those of other leaders is the unavoidable question mark that looms over the genuineness of the gesture...This is precisely what Sanjoy Ghose’s widow, Sumita, once a student of conflict transformation, said when contacted: “Only the Almighty has the power to forgive. I am just a human being and I want justice to be done.” | newspaper =The Telegraph, Calcutta, India | year = | date =9 June 2011 | url =http://www.telegraphindia.com/1110609/jsp/opinion/story_14078142.jsp }}</ref>
==Legacy==
An international appeal for his release carried by the leftist magazine [[Economic and Political Weekly]], summarised his work in Rajasthan and in media advocacy thus; "From 1986 to 1995 Sanjoy did pioneering work in western Rajasthan. He set up URMUL Trust in 1986 in Bikaner with the chief objective of empowering the local people to address their own development needs. By 1995, URMUL expanded into a network of organisations addressing the concerns of the poor in the districts of Bikaner, Jodhpur and Jaisalmer in western Rajasthan. Sanjoy wrote extensively and spiritedly on development issues. He was one of the firsts to realise the need for media advocacy for the NGOs and struggle-based groups, and established CHARKHA as an interface between NGOs and the mainstream media." .<ref>{{cite journal |last1=letters |first1= |year=1997 |title= Appeal For Release of Sanjoy Ghose |journal=Economic and Political Weekly |volume=XXXII |issue=28 July 12, 1997 |pages= |publisher= Sameeksha Trust|url=http://www.epw.in/letters/appeal-release-sanjoy-ghose.html |accessdate=15 January 2013}}</ref>
A couple of decades, after his untimely demise, both his creations, URMUL Trust and CHARKHA continue to survive and grow in the "rural development sector" – URMUL and its affiliates in the desert districts of Rajasthan, and CHARKHA in the world of development media. CHARKHA has instituted the "Sanjoy Ghose Media Fellowships" in his memory. This has been awarded since 2003 in the state of Jammu and Kashmir, to encourage writers, particularly women, to generate research based writings that reflect their unique perspective on the concerns of their people in a region that has known conflicts for several decades now.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charkha.org/html/fellows01.html |title=Media Fellowships |publisher=Charkha.org |date= |accessdate=27 September 2010}}</ref>
In 2011, the award was targeted to women writers from the underdeveloped mountain region of [[Ladakh]]. In 2015, the award had been renamed Sanjoy Ghose Rural Reporting Awards (Ladakh) 2015 <ref>{{cite news | author =ANI | title = Sanjoy Ghose Rural Reporting Awards (Ladakh) 2015 announced | quote =With the aim of recognising the work of writers who have shown the zeal to go beyond the usual and highlight invisible development issues of the women living in the rural borderlands, Charkha Development Communication Network, a Delhi-based nonprofit organization, has announced the Sanjoy Ghose Rural Reporting Awards (Ladakh) 2015. A total of four awards of Rs 20,000 each will be given to well-researched and sharply-focused unpublished writings that are expected to highlight little-known strengths and travails of the women of this remote but significant part of India with a view to bringing them into the mainstream development fold. The Awards, inspired by Charkha's founder, Sanjoy Ghose who worked towards the social and economic inclusion of rural marginalised communities through the creative use of media, offer an opportunity for writers to delve into the challenges faced by the women of rural disadvantaged communities and reflect the status of development as perceived by these women. | newspaper =Business Standard | date = September 8, 2015| url =http://www.business-standard.com/article/news-ani/sanjoy-ghose-rural-reporting-awards-ladakh-2015-announced-115090800629_1.html |access-date= 2015-09-22}}</ref>
A review of Charkha in 2017, stated that "Charkha has since upheld this vision articulated in its mandate "To contribute towards building a harmonious, inclusive society empowered by knowledge".Over the last more than two decades Charkha has translated this into an expansive engagement with rural marginalised communities across several regions in the country.Through its #Tri-lingual Feature Service in Hindi, English and Urdu the organisation continues to place their perspectives as articles in the media across the three languages. Charkha is making all attempts to live up to a phrase coined at the time of its founding " Spinning Action into Words"!" <ref>{{cite web |url=https://in.news.yahoo.com/remembering-charkhas-founder-sanjoy-ghose-063506786.html |title=Remembering Charkha's Founder, Sanjoy Ghose|last1= Raghavan|first1=Sujatha |last2= |first2= |date=5 July 2017 |website=yahoo.com |publisher= |accessdate=20 November 2017}}</ref>
The [[Ashoka: Innovators for the Public]] had instituted the Sanjoy Ghose Endowment in his memory in 1998 for "building a culture of volunteerism and a sense of citizen responsibility among the youth in India's northeastern state of Assam"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ashoka.org/endowments |title=Ashoka's Endowments | Ashoka — Innovators for the Public |publisher=Ashoka |date=4 July 1997 |accessdate=28 March 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130516082329/https://www.ashoka.org/endowments |archive-date=16 May 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ashoka.org/endowments |title=Ashoka's Endowments |access-date=1 October 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150929030345/https://www.ashoka.org/endowments |archive-date=29 September 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The Sanjoy Ghose Memorial Trust Society was formed in the year 2000, in Majuli. The Trust has been holding memorial services every year on 4 July, the day of his disappearance and suspected death.<ref>{{cite news | title =Project to carry on legacy | quote =The Sanjoy Ghose Memorial Trust Society will launch an audio-video project on school documentation in Majuli on Ghose’s 15th memorial day on July 4, in a bid to carry on the social worker’s legacy. | newspaper =The Telegraph, Calcutta, India | date =1 July 2011 | url =http://www.telegraphindia.com/1110701/jsp/northeast/story_14180508.jsp }}</ref> The Trust announced plans to launch an audio-video project on school documentation in Majuli on Ghose’s 15th memorial day on 4 July 2011:in a bid to carry on the social worker’s legacy. <ref>{{cite news | author =PULLOCK DUTTA | title =Project to carry on legacy | quote =The Sanjoy Ghose Memorial Trust Society will launch an audio-video project on school documentation in Majuli on Ghose’s 15th memorial day on July 4, in a bid to carry on the social worker’s legacy. CCTV cameras will be installed at educational institutions in the island and subsequently data would be collected which, the Society feels, will help to improve the education scenario in the island. "We are getting support from the satradhikars and social workers in Majuli to carry on with the project. We are also in touch with the government,” the secretary of the Society, Kishori Mohan Paul, told this correspondent today. Paul said the data would include the methods of teaching by teachers, the student-teacher relationship and the discipline maintained in institutions. There are nearly 800 education institutions in Majuli, of which seven are colleges. | newspaper =The Telegraph, Calcutta, India | year = | date =1 July 2011 | url =http://www.telegraphindia.com/1110701/jsp/northeast/story_14180508.jsp }}</ref> A fictionalised biography on Sanjoy Ghose, written in the Assamese was published in 2008.<ref>{{cite book |title=Mājulīraparā mai Sañjaẏa Ghoshe kaichon̐|publisher=Pāhi Prakāśana |location= |edition= 2008|first=Gobina Kumāra | last=Khāuṇḍa|volume=| language=Assamese |page= |chapter= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MaWzQwAACAAJ&dq=Sanjoy+Ghose&hl=en&sa=X&ei=KQb5Uau2KIPYrQekqIGADA&ved=0CFUQ6AEwCTgK|isbn=}}</ref>
A website in his memory was launched on the fifteenth "smriti divas" (remembrance day) on 4 July 2011 by this trust.<ref>{{cite news | author =Correspondent | title =Website on Sanjoy Ghose launched | quote =A website containing information about Sanjoy Ghose, the team leader of Association of Voluntary Agencies in Rural Development NE, who was killed by the activists of ULFA 15 years ago while working in Majuli, was launched today on the 15th Smriti Divas of the slain social activist at Kamalabari, Majuli. | newspaper =The Assam tribune | date = 5 July 2011| url =http://www.assamtribune.com/scripts/detailsnew.asp?id=jul0511/state06 }}</ref>
His book, Sanjoy's Assam, has been used by the [[2011 Indian anti-corruption movement]], to initiate the anti corruption movement in Assam. <ref>{{cite news | title =Jorhat joins Hazare crusade | quote =Advocate Rintu Goswami stated that the book Sanjoy’s Assam: Diaries and writings of Sanjoy Ghose explicitly depict the kind of corruption he was fighting against on the river island of Majuli before Ulfa killed him. | newspaper =The Telegraph, Calcutta, India | year = | date =10 April 2011 | url =http://www.telegraphindia.com/1110410/jsp/northeast/story_13834143.jsp }}</ref> A bilingual film inspired by his life was made in [[Assamese language|Assamese]] and [[Hindi]], which was directed by Bidyut Kotoky and produced by the [[National Film Development Corporation of India]]. The film was shot in [[Majuli]] and [[Mumbai]].<ref>{{cite news | author = Gaurav Das| title =Film on futility of violence to hit screens soon | quote =The film also focuses on the futility of violence and is inspired by the life of activist Sanjoy Ghose, who was killed by Ulfa in 1997 in Majuli. | newspaper =Times of India | date = 12 September 2012| url =http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-09-12/guwahati/33788252_1_feature-film-sanjay-suri-national-film-development-corporation }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thethumbprintmag.com/life-in-unchartered-majuli-brahmaputra-sanjoy-ghosh-ulfa-as-the-river-flows/ |title=Life in Unchartered Majuli |access-date= 1 October 2015}}</ref> The Assamese version, titled ''[[Ekhon Nedekha Nodir Xhipare]]'', was released on 14 September 2012. The film won two awards for the Best Script and Best Actor at the second edition of the Washington DC South Asian Film Festival.<ref>{{cite news | author = | title =Assamese film bags awards at US fest | quote = Bidyut Kotoky's Ekhon Nedekha Nodir Xhipare bagged two awards for the Best Script and Best Actor at the second edition of the Washington DC South Asian Film Festival...The film stars Bollywood actor Sanjay Suriin the lead role, who won in the Best Actor Award for his portrayal of a journalist who comes to insurgency-hit Assam in search of his friend, a social activist, who goes missing under mysterious conditions. The film is loosely based on the mysterious disappearance of Sanjay Ghose, a social activist, now presumed dead. | newspaper = Times of India| year = | date =May 15, 2013 | url =http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/guwahati/Assamese-film-bags-awards-at-US-fest/articleshow/20059499.cms?referral=PM }}</ref> The film won the Audience Choice Award at the North Carolina International South Asian Film Festival (NCISAFF) for 2014.<ref>{{cite news | author = | title =Victor Banerjee starrer wins audience choice award in US fest| quote = “The Audience Choice Award for 2014 goes to ‘As River Flows’. It was beautifully done,” North Carolina International South Asian Film Festival director Gauri Singh informed the film’s director Bidyut Kotoky.| newspaper = The Indian Express |date=March 19, 2014| url = http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/victor-banerjee-starrer-wins-audience-choice-award-in-us-fest/|access-date=29 June 2016}}</ref> The Hindi version, titled ''As the River Flows'', is yet to release.<ref name="dearcinema">{{cite web | url=http://dearcinema.com/news/bidyut-kotokys-akhon-nedekha-nodir-sipare-releases-today/2810 | title=Bidyut Kotoky’s "Akhon Nedekha Nodir Sipare" releases on Friday | publisher=Dear Cinema | date=14 September 2012 | accessdate=13 January 2013}}</ref>
In 2016 and 2017, students of the [[Institute of Rural Management Anand]], have celebrated his birthday, (7 December) as "Joy Day': by organising a blood donation drive, and hosting a function to remember him in their campus. <ref>{{cite news | author = | title =IRMA to host ‘Joy Day’ today to honour alumnus | quote =The Institute of Rural Management Anand (IRMA) will host 'Joy Day' on Thursday to commemorate the birth anniversary of its celebrated alumnus late Sanjoy Ghose.Ghose, a prominent rural development activist whose pioneering contributions to the development and community health are still remembered, was murdered by the United Liberation Front of Asom (ULFA) in July 1997. Students organize a blood donation drive in association with the Indian Red Cross Society between 3.30 pm and 7.30 pm. In the evening, a session - Remembering Joy - will be held at the IRMA auditorium between 9 pm and 10.30 pm.Ghose's wife Sumita Ghose, managing director of the Gujarat Co-operative Milk Marketing Federation and a prominent alumni of IRMA R S Sodhi and Ghose's colleague at URMUL Rural Health, Research and Development Trust at Bikaner Arvind Ojha will be amongst the speakers. | newspaper = Times of India| date = December 7, 2017| url =https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/vadodara/irma-to-host-joy-day-today-to-honour-alumnus/articleshow/61954010.cms |accessdate= 6 January 2018 }}</ref>
In 37 years Sanjoy Ghose had packed more into life than most people do in a hundred years or more. An article in the prominent political magazine [[Tehelka]], described Sanjoy as "The man who saw tomorrow". It ran a feature on him with the title "Sanjoy Ghose was a dogged catalyst of change. And he paid the ultimate price for it". RN Haldipur, (former director of IRMA),who served on the Board of Tribhuvandas Foundation, when Sanjoy was working there, assessed him thus "Sanjoy was a positive and tenacious votary who functioned with single-minded purpose. Instead of joining the corporate sector, he took the hard path, full of difficulties and austerity. To him work was soul-satisfying worship. Transparent in his dealings, he was a man of great integrity." <ref>{{cite news | author =Deepti Priya Mehrotra | title =The man who saw tomorrow | quote =Sanjoy Ghose was a dogged catalyst of change. And he paid the ultimate price for it | newspaper =Tehelka | date =29 January 2005 | url =http://archive.tehelka.com/story_main10.asp?filename=Cr012905the_man_who.asp | access-date =15 January 2013 | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20160304030347/http://archive.tehelka.com/story_main10.asp?filename=Cr012905the_man_who.asp | archive-date =4 March 2016 | dead-url =yes | df =dmy-all }}</ref>
==Education and career== * Schooled in [[Cathedral and John Connon School]], [[Mumbai]] * Graduate from [[Elphinstone College]], Mumbai, with specialisation in Rural Development and Law, 1977 -1980. * Post graduate degree in Rural Management from IRMA [[Institute of Rural Management, Anand|Institute of Rural Management]] in [[Anand, Gujarat]], 1980–1982. * MSc in Agricultural Economics from [[St Anne's College, Oxford]], United Kingdom with an Inlaks Scholarship.1984–85 * Masters in Public Health, [[Johns Hopkins University]], USA as a [[Hubert Humphrey]] Fellow.1988–89 * Founder Secretary and Trustee, Urmul Rural Health Research & Development Trust, [[Rajasthan]]1986 * Founder general secretary, Charkha, the Development Communications Network, New Delhi1994 * Winner of the 1993 Sanskriti Award * general secretary, Association of Voluntary Agencies in Rural Development (AVARD), New Delhi * Team leader, AVARD North East
His mission in his own words "To change the world and make a difference in the lives of ordinary people".
==Awards== Awarded ''All India Human Rights Association'' Manav Shri Puraskar award in the field of Journalism & Social Welfare, 1997–98.
Awarded [[Karmaveer Puraskaar]] posthumously for Lifelong Fight For Social Justice Through Citizen Action. 2011
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.charkha.org/ Official website of Charka] * [http://www.urmul.org/ Official website of Urmul]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ghose, Sanjay}} [[Category:Activists from Maharashtra]] [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:1997 deaths]] [[Category:Elphinstone College alumni]] [[Category:Alumni of St Anne's College, Oxford]] [[Category:Bengali people]] [[Category:People in public health]] [[Category:Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health alumni]] [[Category:Cathedral and John Connon School alumni]] [[Category:Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health]]
